children.name: JPL-PUB
children.project_abstract: This project encompasses public research that JPL will pursue at TACC

children.name: TG-ATM170020
children.project_abstract:
The numerical simulations proposed here are aimed at calculating accurate Linear Response Functions (LRFs) of Global Climate Models (GCMs). Calculating accurate LRFs of GCMs has been actively pursued in the past four decades by the climate science community because of the broad applications of such LRFs. However, obtaining accurate LRFs has been found challenging, mainly because turbulence, which plays a key role in the dynamics of atmospheric and oceanic circulations, is poorly understood. The proposed research has two objectives:

Objective 1: To calculate accurate LRFs for several model setups of a widely used atmospheric GCM by employing a method recently developed by the PI. This method will be referred to as the Green's Function (GRF) method. The PI used the GRF method to accurately calculate the LRF of this GCM for one model setup. This accurate LRF has been used to study several problems related to extreme weather events and internal climate variability. Calculating the accurate LRFs for several model setups will allow us to study a wider range of important problems in climate dynamics.

Objective 2: The main drawback of the GRF method is that it is computationally demanding. The second objective is to investigate whether any data-driven method can produce the LRFs with accuracy comparable to that of the GRF method but at a lower computational cost. The performance of several data-driven methods has been found to be poor by various researchers in the past, but the reason(s) behind the poor performance (i.e., low accuracy) is unknown. Another application of the accurate LRFs calculated using the GRF method is that they can be used to identify the source(s) of the poor performance of data-driven methods, as recently demonstrated by PI.

children.name: TG-ATM140018
children.project_abstract: The Sahel is a diverse climatic region that includes a semi-arid tropical zone in the north and a humid tropical climate zone to the south. Understanding Sahelian climate seasonal, interannual, and decadal variability and anomaly has been recognized as a critical component in global climate studies by international programs, such as CLIVAR, GEWEX, and AMMA.  The more severe drought in the last century in the world, strong coupling between Sahel climate and external forcings, the controversy on the causes of the Sahel climate anomalies, especially the drought, and its significant social and economic implications make this region extremely important for the scientific community.   This project will contribute to identification of the attribution of Sahel rainfall changes to anthropogenic and natural drivers, and the effect of climate variability on its ecosystems and water resources

children.name: TG-ATM190008
children.project_abstract: Globally, large-scale agriculture and electricity generation require reliable access to water resources, yet it is difficult to predict how changes in one system, such as the impact of climate change on water availability, will impact the others. California presents a case study due to its large agricultural production and its dependence on snowmelt for water resources. In drought years, due to low snow accumulation and the resulting decreased streamflow, groundwater is pumped for irrigation, increasing electricity demand. The observational record suggests that snow accumulation is declining in the Sierra Nevada and that river runoff is peaking earlier in the spring, potentially weeks earlier than the peak in demand for agriculture and human consumption. If snow accumulation declines and precipitation patterns change, both the agricultural and electrical energy sectors of California will need to adapt. Here we examine the hydroclimate component of the agriculture-electricity-water system by estimating how the climate of California may change throughout the twenty-first century. We will perform model simulations with the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) regional climate model where we downscale coarse-resolution global climate model projections from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). By using a regional climate model like WRF, we can simulate hydroclimate conditions at high spatial resolution, which is important for realistic estimates of orographic precipitation, a major driver of snow accumulation in the Sierra Nevada mountains. In order to capture a range of future conditions, we propose to downscale two global climate models and two different emission scenarios. By comparing simulations from the mid-century (2039-2050) and end-of-century (2089-2100) to the historical period (1994-2005), we aim to understand how precipitation and snow accumulation spatiotemporal patterns may change. Though not all snowfall is expected to switch to rainfall by the end of the twenty-first century, a decrease in snowfall percentage is likely to impact both the spatial and temporal patterns of annual precipitation, which will impact timing and magnitude of river runoff. WRF simulations will be shared with project collaborators to estimate how the agriculture and energy sectors may be impacted by projected climate change, linking the hydrology and climate of California to water resource, agriculture, and energy generation models.

children.name: TG-MCA94P017
children.project_abstract: An allocation is requested for large scale computer simulations of multiple and single proton transport (PT) in biomolecular systems, coarse-graining, and large multi-scale simulations of biological assemblies. In the case of PT, the interaction of the proton with the biomolecular environment is represented by the multi-state empirical valence bond (MS-EVB) method, and the potential of mean force (PMF) along the pathway of PT is calculated by averaging over highly parallel swarms of trajectories. A novel methodology to simulate multiple protons, based on the MS-EVB, has just been developed by our group and scales nearly linearly with proton number. Large atomistic simulations of biological assemblies will be performed in order to systematically parameterize coarse-grained mesoscopic models that will be employed to examine long time- and length-scale phenomena. Multi-scale coupled simulations of embedded proteins in lipid bilayers, as well as spectrin filaments will be employed to directly examine atomistic-level couplings with mesoscopic phenomena. These studies are extremely challenging and well suited to parallel supercomputing environments.

children.name: TG-CHE190039
children.project_abstract:
The overall objective of the proposed research is to leverage multiscale molecular modeling techniques including wave-function methods, density functional theory, QM/MM calculations and machine learning to investigate complex phenomena in zeolites. Specifically, this project will focus on two thrusts, which are organized by application: (1) methane partial oxidation using cation-exchanged zeolites and (2) regio-selective epoxide ring opening reactions using Lewis-acid zeolites. Using multiscale modeling approaches, these studies will lead to significant advances in understanding (1) formation of active sites under reaction conditions and (2) liquid phase reactions in confined pores. Based on the initial benchmarking results obtained on TACC/Stampede2 system (startup allocation TG-DMR170124), we estimate that ~45k service units (i.e. 44,340 node-hours) on Stampede2 will be necessary.  
Note: This proposal had been submitted in the previous XRAS cycle. The reviewer comments indicated that additional justification of requested computational resources is necessary. These concerns have been specifically addressed by including a detailed discussion of the computational costs for various calculations to be performed.

children.name: TG-CHE190010
children.project_abstract: One of the most significant challenges for the computational understanding of current materials and the design of new materials for energy storage and conversion is the limitation in accessible time scales. A direct simulation of atomic motion is limited to picoseconds when the forces and energies are based upon density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The relevant timescale for the function of batteries and fuel cells, however, are on a human timescale of second to minutes. In this proposal we will develop the adaptive kinetic Monte Carlo method for use with DFT codes to model novel materials that can function as electrolytes and electrodes in Li batteries and solid oxide fuel cells which can accelerate and select reactions of interest. The parallel resources offered by the XSEDE program will allow us to explore the potential energy surface around stable states and determine the mechanism and rates of possible reaction mechanisms. We have, and will continue over the duration of this project, to develop the EON code which manages the individual calculations that identify saddle points on the potential landscape which correspond to each possible reaction mechanism and collects the information to evolve the system over timescales set by the elementary reaction mechanisms. Importantly, this methodology does not require intuition from the user so that reaction pathways are determined automatically and can be surprising and complex, if that is the nature of the potential energy landscape. We show, in this proposal, that we will be able to efficiently use the XSEDE resources for these calculations. This project will also enable us to accomplish the goals set out in our NSF funded projects to improve the efficiency of our computational methods as well as model intercalation and diffusion in battery materials and the chemistry at catalytic surfaces.

children.name: TG-CHE060073N
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-CHE140141
children.project_abstract: An international research team consisting of Ilja Siepmann, Ben Lynch (University of Minnesota), Neeraj Rai (Mississippi State University), Troy Van Voorhis (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), Ben Slater (University College London), Michiel Sprik (University of Cambridge), Adam Carter (Edinburgh Parallel Computing Centre), Jrg Hutter (University of Zurich), I-Feng Kuo (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory), Christopher Mundy (Pacific Northwest National Laboratory), Joost VandeVondele (ETH Zurich), and Rodolphe Vuilleumier (University Pierre & Marie Curie Paris) is collaborating to develop and implement new theoretical methods in the CP2K computational chemistry software suite. These new methodologies enable the predictive modeling of reactive multi-phase systems, including free energy landscapes and product yields, where the system interactions are described by Kohn-Sham density functional theory with van der Waals and hybrid functionals. Markov chain Monte Carlo approaches utilizing smart moves with asymmetric underlying matrices, such as the aggregation-volume-bias and configurational-bias Monte Carlo methods, and the Gibbs ensemble framework are employed for efficient exploration of the phase space for reactive single- and multi-phase equilibria in bulk and in confinement. As the reactive and sorption phase equilibria is extremely sensitive to intermolecular potentials, here we evaluate suitability of different density functionals to predict phase equilibria of systems characterized by weak interactions.

children.name: TG-PHY190020
children.project_abstract:
The LIGO-Virgo Scientific Collaborations have already detected gravitational wave signals from the inspiral and merger of ten binary black holes, and the inspiral of a binary neutron star (event GW170817). GW170817 was also observed across the electromagnetic
spectrum by over 70 observatories. These breakthroughs ushered in the era of gravitational wave and multimessenger astronomy, allowing us to probe gravity and matter in unprecedented regimes. Robust, first-principles theoretical modeling of multimessenger sources is necessary both to build templates for detecting gravitational wave signals in upcoming observations, and for the interpretation of existing and future multimessenger signals. Such modeling requires supercomputer simulations of gravitational wave sources by solving the Einstein equations coupled to matter, electromagnetic fields and radiation. Several groups are performing such simulations focusing on subsets of the vast parameter space of compact binaries that must be explored to achieve complete understanding of the problem; our group has substantial expertise studying compact binary mergers, circumbinary accretion onto binary black holes, and the nuclear equation of state. The simulations proposed here will advance the state-of-the-art on all these fronts. In particular, we propose to perform the first systematic studies of the effects of realistic, finite temperature component of the nuclear equation of state in binary neutron star mergers, and the impact of black hole spin in magnetized accretion disks onto binary black holes.

children.name: TG-MCA09X003
children.project_abstract:
Having constructed a scalable code capable of evolving astrophysically
relevant systems including magnetized neutron stars and black holes,
we request time to continue our runs towards further understanding of
these strong field phenomena. In particular, our code uses MPI and
AMR to make efficient use of large scale computational resources
as well as advanced computational techniques such as higher order
finite differencing, high resolution shock capturing for
magnetohydrodynamics, and black hole excision  in order to evolve
such systems while extracting useful information about the produced
gravitational wave signatures. Further efforts are underway to 
increase the scalability as well as add the ability to track
radiation transport.

children.name: TG-PHY060027N
children.project_abstract:
We will use our fully general relativistic evolution scheme to perform
high-accuracy calculations of several astrophysical phenomena,
focusing in the next year on black-hole binaries in the extreme mass
and extreme spin regimes, as well as the mergers of stellar-mass black
holes with neutron stars and the resulting accretion disk formed by
the disruption of the neutron star and the dynamics of a circumbinary
accretion disk around a merging black-hole binary.  In order to do this, we will
combine our state-of-the-art, highly-scalable, parallel vacuum
evolution code, which makes use of both high-order (typically
eighth-order) finite differencing and adaptive mesh refinement, with
similarly high-order magnetohydrodynamic schemes that allow for the
evolution of magnetized matter configurations with comparable
accuracy.  These calculations are highly relevant to a number of
fields within both gravitational wave and electromagnetic astronomy.
In particular, the gravitational wave signals produced by these
mergers occur primarily at frequencies at which ground-based laser
interferometers such as LIGO and VIRGO are most sensitive.  In
addition, the extremely hot, massive accretion disks formed around the
black hole during the merger are considered a likely candidate for
being the progenitor for a significant fraction of short-duration
gamma-ray bursts observed by the Swift and HETE-II satellites. MHD simulations
of accretions disks around supermassive black holes (including binaries) will
also be performed.

children.name: TG-PHY990007N
children.project_abstract: Gravitational waves from the final inspiral, plunge and merger of compact binaries with black holes and neutron stars are primary targets for gravitational wave detectors. While analytic methods such as the post-Newtonian approximation and effective one-body (EOB) formalism can be used to predict wave forms for most of the inspiral, wave forms from the final few orbits, plunge, and merger can be predicted only by large-scale numerical computations. The EOB formalism can be used to construct templates for gravitational wave data analysis by adding parameters that can be calibrated with numerical simulations.  These calibrations, however, require very accurate numerical simulations.  We propose to do a series of simulations and calibrate the EOB waveforms with the results of our simulations for binary systems with non-equal black hole masses as well as arbitrary black hole spins. Neutron stars merging with stellar mass black holes are potentially sources of short duration gamma-ray bursts, depending upon how much of an accretion disk is formed during the merger.  We plan to explore the dependence of the disk formation on the mass ratio, spin of the black hole, and the currently unknown equation of state describing the neutron star.

children.name: TG-PHY120016
children.project_abstract:
This renewal proposal seeks the continuation of our EXEDE Resources Allocation in support of our numerical relativityeffort on simulations of compact objects and their impact on astrophysics and gravitational astronomy.  Numerical relativity has truly become a tool of discovery. For gravitational wave astrophysics, it has enabled a serious conversation between researchers modeling sources of gravitational radiation and scientists focussed on the intricacies of analyzing the
data collected by interferometric detectors.  The black hole binaries continues to be one of the most transformative challenges at the interface of gravitational wave physics, astrophysics, mathematical relativity and computational
science. The challenge resides in the complexities associated with solving Einstein's equations; in the many scales involved, from those comparable to the binary orbits or gravitational wavelengths to those in the vicinity of the black holes; in the resolutions needed to accurately extract gravitational waveforms; and in the inclusion of physics to model matter sources. 
The allocation requested will support  work on  binary  black holes systems organized in the following closely related project areas: 1) Binary black holes in vacuum to expand parameter space explored to include arbitrary black hole spin orientations and to enhance a bank of  hybrid gravitational waveforms.
2) Binary black holes in astrophysical environments to investigate whether electromagnetic observations are able to detect and characterize the presence of these binary systems. 
3)Binary black holes in alternative theories of gravity to study the late inspiral and merger of a binary coalescences and distinguish between scalar-tensor gravity and general relativity.

children.name: TG-PHY160053
children.project_abstract:
We seek XSEDE computer time to numerically simulate the merger of relativistic, astrophys-
ical compact objects with the goal of predicting the generated gravitational waveforms, and use
them for template modeling for advanced LIGO (aLIGO). There are two avenues of science that
will be investigated in this proposal, each spearheaded by a senior postdoctoral researcher or
senior research programmer in the Gravity Group at the National Center for Supercomputing
Applications (NCSA), University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC). NCSA is a mem-
ber of the LIGO Scientific Consortium (LSC), all co-PIs are LIGO members, and the XSEDE
allocation will primarily support research which is part of the NCSA LIGO activities.
 We will study the reliability of physical predictions for binary neutron star (BNS) merger
waveforms by current numerical codes. BNS mergers are one of the prime targets for
gravitational waves (GWs) detectable by aLIGO, yet there is no work that tries to validate
the predicted GWs between different numerical codes. Such a comparison, performed in
the numerical relativity and analytical relativity (NRAR) project for binaries black holes
(BBHs), will improve the confidence in the predictions of these numerical simulations,
and their use in model construction for aLIGO.
 As part of our LIGO reviewed contribution to LIGO science goals, we will construct
a model for GWs emitted by the mergers of spinning BBHs on eccentric orbits. One
of the most exciting prospects in the next aLIGOs observing runs is the detection of
eccentric GW signals, since these events will provide unique insights about the binary
assembly process. Even if no detection of eccentric binaries is obtained, the use of
eccentric waveform templates is of critical importance to exclude a significant dynamically
assembled population of compact binaries that merge in dense stellar environments.
Co-PIs of this proposal are leading the development of eccentric waveform models in the
LIGO Scientific Collaboration to realize this science. Recent research highlights include
the development of the first time domain waveform model that describes the inspiral,
merger and ringdown of compact binary systems whose components are non-spinning,
and which evolve on orbits with low to moderate eccentricity. Using this model, we
carried out the first comprehensive analysis on the effect of eccentricity in the detection
of the GW transients GW150914 and GW151226. This allocation will enable us
to develop from the ground up state-of-the-art waveform models that describe the merger
of spinning BHs on eccentric orbits. As we have done in the past, we will implement these
new models in LIGOs Algorithm Library (LAL) for their use in actual GW searches.
Our research group consists of 1 faculty member, 4 senior postdoctoral research scholars, 1
senior research programmer, 1 graduate student and 2 undergraduate students. We propose
to use our open-source, community infrastructure Einstein Toolkit for these simulations and
request a total of 6.04 million SU and 1 TB of long-term storage in support for the
proposed research.

children.name: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCA06N060
children.project_abstract:
In this renewal application, we request time to continue our investigation of the mechanism of several membrane transporters and channels using simulation methodologies. Several active transporters that use various source of energy in a living cell for their function will be investigated. Furthermore, we will also continue our research on another membrane associated phenomenon, namely mechanism of membrane binding and activation of blood coagulation factors, which constitutes the most productive project over the past funding period, and a strong collaborative effort between 5 labs at UIUC.  In fact, all of the projects are conducted in close collaboration with leading experimental groups.   All Projects address rather slow processes, thus, requiring long simulations. Furthermore, due to the need of explicit representation of the lipid and water, which play role in the mechanism of transporters, and due to the complexity of the structure, large molecular assemblies need to be simulated. Such calculations can only be carried out with the advanced TeraGrid computational resources. The size and
complexity of the function of these proteins pose a great challenge for computational studies. Over the last funding period, however, we have demonstrated through several published papers reported in the Progress Report, that large scale MD simulations can indeed significantly advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of energy coupling and transport phenomena in these biomolecules. Due to limited space and the need to describe 6 projects, we have delegated the progress and discussion of our preliminary results
completely to the Progress Report. Our extensive use of the allocation over the past funding period is the strongest evidence for the computational demands of such biomolecular systems. We note, however, that we have used the allocated time extremely productively and produced a record number of publications (16; please see Progress Report) over the past funding cycle. We would like to give a general clarification with regard to the length of the proposed simulations, which might be perceived as an "unjustified" aspect. All of the projects address rather slow biomolecular processes (at least on the
order of microsecond). As such, even orders of magnitude longer simulations than those described in this application
can be easily justified from a technical point of view. However, we realize that such processes (e.g., complete transport cycle) cannot be currently described in their entirety, and we can only expect to cover some of the steps involved in such processes. Therefore, in order to provide a justification that will hopefully
be satisfactory, almost in all cases we will base the length of the proposed simulations on our existing benchmarks (mostly published) of the same or comparable systems/phenomena.

children.name: TG-MCB180055
children.project_abstract: This work will use molecular dynamics simulations and vibrational frequency calculations to quantitatively interpret experimental data from vibrational probe groups with unique frequencies.  Vibrational probe groups in proteins provide data in which the structural ensemble is in slow exchange and directly appears in the lineshape, unlike most other protein analytical techniques.  We have recently cemented an approach that can provide quantitatively interpretability from vibrational probe lineshapes and directly link those lineshapes to physical and structural changes in the protein.  This computational allocation will be used to predict structural ensembles (through replica exchange simulations), to run short trajectories on submembers of those ensembles with the probe groups included, and to calculate the vibrational frequencies throughout the MD trajectories to provide lineshapes which could connect our extensive experimental data to dynamic structural ensembles. Constituting such a connection would be highly significant for many different proteins; this allocation will focus on three proteins: calmodulin (our test system), viral replicative complexes from the Hendra and Nipah viruses, and acyl carrier proteins.

children.name: TG-MCB070073N
children.project_abstract:
200,000 supplement SU's are requested for the following molecular simulations:
1.  Docking, equilibration, and free energy calculations of insulin and insulin-like growth factor (IGF) type 1 on the on the IGF-1 receptor.
2.  Development of a novel non-equilibrium simulation of "conformational diffusion" in the acetylcholine-gated ion channel.
3.  Targeted molecular dynamics simulations of conformational changes in the HIV-1 gp120 envelope protein.

children.name: TG-MCB100140
children.project_abstract: The proposed research work involves two projects, both involving nucleic acid systems. The first project is aimed at relating polycation chemistry and architecture to polycation-DNA complexation, for design of polycations for DNA delivery. This is funded by NSF -DMR biomaterials. This project uses a combination of atomistic and coarse-grained (unbiased) molecular dynamics simulations.The second project is aimed at understanding the structure and thermodynamics of single and double stranded DNA near surfaces of varying chemistries, specifically varying hydrophobicities. This project uses primarily atomistic biased molecular dynamics simulations.

children.name: TG-MCB190046
children.project_abstract: Inwardly rectifying potassium (Kir) channels regulate cell excitability in multiple tissues and are key modulators of cardiac and vascular electrical activity and contractility1. They are ligand gated ion channels with membrane lipids being their primary regulators. Phosphoinositol-4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) is the absolutely required agonist for all Kir channel subfamilies while cholesterol exhibits mixed effects depending on subfamily types, and bulk anionic lipids prevalent in cytosolic leaflet of the plasma membranes are positive allosteric effector for Kir2 subfamily2,3. Kir channels should adopt several different functional states depending on differential regulatory lipid binding as well as pore blocker binding. Although a few Kir channel crystal structures have been determined4-9, the three-dimensional structures in each functional state are yet to be elucidated and dynamic properties of the channels is almost absent, which limits our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of channel function and hence the opportunities to develop small molecules to access specific states. We aim to fill up these holes in our knowledge of Kir channel gating through combining experimental approaches (x-ray crystallography, single particle-EM, single molecule FRET, in vitro functional assays, and electrophysiology) and computational modeling (docking and molecular dynamics simulations), which will advance our knowledge of how these channels undergo various conformations as well as dynamic states throughout their functional cycles.

children.name: TG-MCB150054
children.project_abstract: We request XSEDE allocations to study the Ras family of surface-bound proteins that regulate a variety of cell signaling pathways and LAT proteins involved in TCR-mediated signaling.  Malfunction of Ras proteins leads to many forms of cancer and developmental disorders, and there is an urgent need for therapeutic agents to abrogate defective Ras signaling. As part of our broader effort toward developing effective anti-cancer therapeutics by directly targeting Ras, we propose to conduct large-scale molecular dynamics simulations to study the structure, dynamics and druggability of Ras monomers and oligomers in solution and membrane environments. We will also investigate the roles of trans-membrane length, palmitoylation and amino acid sequence in determining membrane domain preferences and dimerization of LAT.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston

children.name: TG-CTS090004
children.project_abstract: The goal of this research is twofold: (i) to understand the role of turbulence in the generation of sound in modern aircraft turbo-machinery, and (ii) to develop computational methods for controlling the sound.   It is well known that certain geometrical modifications to aircraft engines can reduce their radiated noise.  However, there is no manner to predict which modifications will actually reduce the noise, resulting in lengthy---and costly---experimental programs to parametrically study candidate design modifications.  This deficiency is due to the conceptual, experimental, and computational challenges associated with turbulence-generated sound and, hence, in developing effective control methods.  By solving the compressible Navier-Stokes equations directly, this research provides foundational descriptions of the sound-generating fluid motions and subsequent development of optimized control methodologies.  The PI's code is based on advanced finite difference techniques and scales at 90\% of perfect up to 1024 processors on TACC's Ranger.  This work follows up the previous DACs TG-CTS080019 (DJB) and TG-CTS080030N (JBF).  Financial support for this work is provided by three separate grants from NASA and the AeroAcoustics Research Consortium on which the current investigators are PI's or co-PI.  It builds upon large-scale aeroacoustic simulation work from past NASA and AFOSR grants.  Total requested allocation is 14,000K SUs.

children.name: Large-scale-simulati
children.project_abstract: A novel type of real-time simulation/optimization technique is being developed  to capture the dynamic nature of trajectory of the released chemical using an integrated weather-forecasting-chemistry plume transport model (WRF-CHEM) that simultaneously simulates the emission, turbulent mixing, transport, transformation, and fate of trace gases and aerosols. We have developed cooperative control laws and an optimal model based estimation filter for coupled problems of cooperative  control and sensing coordination, scheduling and planning of sensing activities, and estimation and prediction of a mobile chemical plume.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

children.name: Propulsors
children.project_abstract: Computational hydrodynamics for propulor design

children.name: TG-CTS100002
children.project_abstract: Heart disease is the single most consequential disease in the industrialized world and current trends point to a worsening outlook. The thesis of the current research is that transformative ideas in modeling, computation and analysis of cardiac blood flows and associated heart sound can enable highly effective and inexpensive simulation-guided therapies and diagnostic tools for heart diseases in the not-too-distant future. Understanding cardiac flows, especially inside the left ventricle, is an essential first step to diagnosing and treating several heart related diseases. Numerous efforts have been made in analyzing cardiac flows over the past two decades through in-vitro (e.g., laboratory PIV measurements), in-vivo (e.g., phase contrast MRI) experiments and computational methods. Though medical imaging techniques such as phase contrast MRI, CT, etc., provide details about the anatomy and some gross features of the flow, not much insight related to complex fluid behavior can be obtained using these approaches. Most of the computational and laboratory (in-vitro) studies have employed simplified geometries while attempting to match physiological values in terms of key hemodynamic parameters, and ignored pivotal interactions between heart flexible tissues, especially heart valves, and complex flow patterns inside heart chambers. The long-term goal of the current project is to develop image-based, biophysically-detailed, multi-scale, multi-physics models of the ventricular blood flows in health and disease that run efficiently on large-scale, CPU/GPU clusters, and to use these models to understand the biophysics of cardiac dysfunction. In this year, we will i) validate the computational modeling of cardiac flow against the in-vivo MRI measurements, ii) investigate the effect of structural dynamics of heart valve and its interaction with hemodynamics, and iii) biochemical process on the development of heart diseases.

children.name: TG-CTS130034
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-CTS070067N
children.project_abstract: This renewal proposal is a request for computational resources at the Indiana University IBM e1350 (Big Red), the TACC Sun Constellation cluster (Ranger), and the HPSS tape storage at SDSC, to be used in our ongoing studies of turbulent drag reduction by dilute polymer solutions. The studies planned for the upcoming year will focus on development of practical skin-friction drag reduction technologies for transportation inspired by the mechanisms observed in polymer drag reduction. A cornerstone of these studies is some recent preliminary DNS studies performed in our lab which show that in turbulent channel flow, MDR conditions can be achieved with the polymer force activated only in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer. This observation opens up new possibilities for developing practical drag reduction technologies for use in transportation. The simulations planned for the upcoming year will include: (i) more detailed simulations of turbulent channel flow with the polymer force activated only in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer; (ii) simulations of turbulent channel flow with a sharp viscosity gradient imposed in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer; (iii) simulations of turbulent channel flow with a wire mesh in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer; and (iv) simulations of turbulent channel flow with flexible fibers in the viscous sub-layer and the buffer layer. The principle action of all these drag reduction technologies is to redirect a small portion of turbulence kinetic energy at the location of the peak of turbulence production in the buffer layer into a path other than the normal turbulent energy cascade. This re-routing of the turbulence kinetic energy at a given turbulent scale results in a drop in the fluctuating strain rate at that scale which, in turn, inhibits the ability of turbulence to redistribute the kinetic energy at that scale from the streamwise to the cross-stream directions through the pressure-strain term.  This results in a pileup of kinetic energy in the streamwise direction and a drop of kinetic energy in the cross-stream directions, which leads to an overall drop in the Reynolds shear-stress and a concomitant drop turbulence production, thus leading to turbulence suppression and drag reduction. These are the principle mechanisms at work in drag reduction by dilute polymer solutions. A total of 400,000 SUs is requested for these studies. Because the IU BigRed will be decommissioned from Teragrid service in March 2010, the requested allocation is split between IU, which we plan to use up to March 2010, and TACC Ranger which we plan to use thereafter. The requested tape storage at SDSC HPSS is for existing data which we have stored at this facility over the past seven years.

children.name: TG-CTS190024
children.project_abstract: The proposed project is to investigate the spray formation in airblast atomization through direct numerical simulation. This physical process is important to liquid fuel injection in aerospace systems. The velocity discrepancy between the injected gas and liquid streams triggers a shear instability at the interface, forming wavy structures on the interface. The interfacial waves grow and eventually break into small droplets, forming a two-phase mixing layer. This so-called airblast atomization process has been shown to be an effective way to produce fine sprays compared to other fuel injectors. The characteristics of the sprays generated by fuel injectors have a direct impact on the mixing between fuel and oxidizer and the subsequent combustion. The overarching goal of the proposed project is to investigate the spray formation in airblast atomization process through direct numerical simulations and to provide rigorous data to characterize the interfacial stability development, the topology changes, and the multiphase turbulence generated in atomization.

children.name: DNS-2phase-mixing
children.project_abstract:
The present project is to investigate spray formation in a two-phase mixing layer between parallel gas and liquid streams through direct numerical simulation. The two-phase mixing layer formed between parallel gas and liquid streams is an important fundamental problem in turbulent multiphase flows. The problem is relevant to many industrial application and natural phenomena, such as air-blast atomizers in fuel injection systems and breaking waves in the ocean. 

The open-source multiphase flow solver, PARIS-Simulator, which was developed by the PI and collaborators will be used for the simulation of the present project. The volume-of-fluid method is employed to capture the interface separating the gas and liquid. The mesh resolution is set to be sufficiently fine to fully resolve the interfacial dynamics and two-phase turbulence. 

The specific goal of the present project is to investigate the effect of the inlet turbulence intensity on development of two-phase mixing layer. A digital filter based approach is employed to introduce turbulent fluctuations at the inflow boundary. Parametric studies will be performed.

children.name: TG-CTS120005
children.project_abstract: This is a renewal request for the project originally titled "Direct Numerical Simulation of Bubble Dynamics in Deformable Vessels", supported through allocation TG-CTS120005. Following the success of the previous allocation, detailed in the Progress Report, we request the following resources to include two additional research efforts from our group. As part of our continuing investigations into the fundamental mechanics of complex fluid flows using numerical simulations, we request 4.95M SU on Kraken and 3.01M SU on the Gordon Compute Cluster, as well as 158.52 TB of disk space. Using Kraken resources, we propose to investigate the multiscale physics of droplet breakup for multiphase nozzle flow applications. In full three-dimensional simulations solving the Navier-Stokes equations, parametric studies will examine the effects of post-shock Mach number and viscosity on the droplet breakup process. The resources on the Gordon Compute Cluster will be used to study three-dimensional instabilities and vortical structures in complex wake flows. Using a novel immersed boundary method based on lattice Green's functions, we propose direct numerical simulations of separated flows at Reynolds numbers ranging from 1,000 to 50,000.

children.name: TG-CTS190041
children.project_abstract:
Sedimenting particles and motile organisms are ubiquitously found in oceans and lakes, where density stratification naturally occurs due to
temperature or salinity gradients. We explore the effects of stratification on the fundamental hydrodynamics of settling particles and small organisms. These process play a controlling role in geophysical processes such as the carbon transfer from upper ocean and trophic dynamics. The goal of the proposed research is to quantify the effects of density stratification, turbulence and shear, motility and shape of microorganisms on the microstructure formation and accumulation of planktonic species by developing a large-scale computational framework to fully resolve the corresponding flows. Through implementing three-dimensional Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS) of nonlinear equations governing transport of organisms and particles, new insights will be gained into the mechanisms governing the distribution of planktonic organisms and particles at pycnoclines. We will also explore our numerical methodâ??s large-scale computing performance. The purpose of such calculations is to demonstrate our numerical methodâ??s scaling efficiency.

children.name: TG-CTS160009
children.project_abstract:
The long-term research goal of the PIs group is to contribute to the fundamental understanding of flow and transport phenomena relevant to the design of sustainable urban environments, such that the uncertainty in computational predictions of these phenomena can be quantified and, where possible, reduced. The computational research that is the topic of the present proposal focuses on performing simulations that will contribute to the understanding of the uncertainty related to the use of Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) turbulence and turbulent heat transfer models by using high-fidelity data sets obtained from large-eddy simulations (LES). The requested computational resources will be used to perform LES simulations required to generate data sets for two different applications of interest to the PIs research group: flow and pollutant dispersion in urban environments and heat transfer. 
In the context of pollutant dispersion we propose to perform LES of the flow and dispersion in downtown Oklahoma City. We previously published a turbulence model form uncertainty quantification study for RANS simulations of this geometry, showing very promising results. The availability of high-fidelity LES data has the potential to significantly increase the impact of this study, since the data will support a detailed investigation and validation of the methodology. The LES simulation results will demonstrate whether the turbulence model form uncertainty quantification method does effectively provide realistic bounds for the prediction of the flow field, and will also be used to guide further development of the method. 
The LES simulations with heat transfer will consider realistic heat exchanger geometries to obtain a high-fidelity data base of the Reynolds stresses and the turbulent heat fluxes. This database will be used to establish and validate a novel methodology to quantify uncertainty in turbulent heat flux models. The results will be analyzed to address two main questions, similar to those previously considered for development of the Reynolds stress model uncertainty quantification method: 1) define a marker that indicates in which regions of the flow the turbulent heat flux model plausibly fails and 2) define perturbations of the turbulent heat fluxes that result in the prediction of realistic upper and lower uncertainty bounds for the temperature field.

children.name: DesignSafe-CERA
children.project_abstract: Per the DesignSafe allocations policy, Tim Cockerill setting up this project for Dr. Carola Kaiser of LSU.

children.name: TG-OCE180010
children.project_abstract:
We request computing and storage capacity on the XSEDE Bridges cluster in order to per-
form high-resolution direct numerical simulation (DNS) of breaking waves in deep and shallow
water, a multiscale problem. The resource request is for an amount of 8 million CPU-hours,
or 167,000SUs on the Stampede2 SKX cluster. The purpose of the research is to obtain well-
resolved numerical data on spray and droplet formation, transport and entrainment into the
atmosphere resulting from the breaking action of the wave. This phenomenon, along with the
complementary process of bubble entrainment, constitutes an important but poorly understood
part of climate dynamics, and is responsible to a large degree for the energy transfer between
the ocean and the atmosphere. The simulations will be conducted using the Basilisk code to
solve the viscous incompressible Navier-Stokes equations in water and air, modelling surface
tension. Basilisk is the successor of the proven Gerris Flow Solver, which has previously been
used for problems of this kind to great eect. Scaling exercises have been performed by the PI on
an XSEDE startup grant on the requested cluster, among others, which informs the requested
amount of SUs. This project will be undertaken by the PI at the Mechanical & Aerospace
Engineering Department at Princeton University, in the research group led by L. Deike. The
personnel and incidental equipment are funded by the Princeton Environmental Institute.

children.name: TG-OCE190008
children.project_abstract: Increasingly, management of coastal waters requires a holistic understanding of how hydrodynamics, morphodynamics, and ecological processes interact. These waters are at the interface between ocean sciences and earth sciences. These interactions are complex in that they change as the climate changes. We wish to conduct student modeling projects that will expose graduate students to the basics of how to model these processes and their interactions. Sensitivity studies will be carried out in which the boundary conditions (river flow, sediment inputs, vegetation cover, etc.) are varied and the students will model the evolution of the estuarine and coastal characteristics. This process-based modeling approach will allow students to develop a robust understanding of these dynamic and important environments. We will be using the coupled ADCIRC-SWAN modeling framework which is very mature and has a strong user-base, ensuring that the studies will have adequate support.

children.name: TG-OCE160020
children.project_abstract:
This allocation request provides support for two NSF-funded projects: (i) NSF OCE-1538702 and (ii) NSF ANT-1543388, both related to simulating ocean mesoscale eddy dynamics. 

The goal of (i) is to adapt existing ocean eddy parametrizations to continental slopes, and thereby improve the fidelity of predictive ocean and climate models. We will develop a suite of eddy-resolving process simulations with steep bottom topography. These will be used to analyze various dynamical aspects of mesoscale turbulence over steep slopes, such as the inverse energy cascade and routes to dissipation of momentum and energy. We will use these simulations to develop and test a new parametrization of eddy transport and mixing over steep slopes.

The goal of (ii) is to develop a high-resolution regional ocean/sea ice model of the Weddell Sea, allowing us to analyze the relative influences of tides, eddies and larger- scale currents on water mass transport and transformation in a site that is critical for the global ocean overturning circulation. Specifically, we will use the model output identify the relative roles of tides and eddies in transporting water masses across the continental slope, in moving water masses around the continental shelf, and in mixing and entrainment between these water masses.

children.name: Ion-permeation
children.project_abstract:
Lipid membranes are vital for all living organisms. They can provide a barrier to prevent exchange between the inner and outer parts of the cell. However, still some types of ions can permeate directly from that depending on the type and composition of the membrane.
The mechanism of this passive permeation of ions is still under debate and some aspects of it is unknown. For positively charged ions, like potassium, the interaction with the charged phosphate head groups plays an important role in the permeation. Computer simulation are one of the powerful tools to shed light on this phenomenon.

In this project, a new set of reaction coordinates will be introduced to consider the interaction of the potassium ion with phosphate groups. The complete pathway of the permeation will be found in the space of these new reaction coordinates by means of a well-known method called Milestoning in which the thermodynamics and kinetics of this permeation will be obtained. The results will be compared to the available experimental data. 

This start up project will be done on potassium. This allocation will be helpful to understand and test these set of reaction coordinate for a research plan for different types of ions with different charges and sizes which we expect to submit later as a research allocation project.

For this study NAMD software will be used which is available on Lonestar 5.

We need to cover a region of 35*35 Angstroms with resolution of 1 Angstrom to find the thermodynamics and kinetics of this permeation. To achieve our goal we need to set up 35*35=1225 short simulations of 0.5 nanosecond each. This is equivalent to ~0.6 microseconds in total. The benchmarks obtained for a similar system to be approximately 14-15ns/day  on Lonestar 5 if we use 2 node/day (48SU). So the whole project can be performed with a 2100SU startup project on Lonestar5.

All the analysis will be performed on the local computers after moving the files.
The result is expected to be published in a peer reviewed journal.
children.pi_institution: Institute for Computational Engineering and Science

children.name: TG-MCB190112
children.project_abstract: Our research group maintains a major focus on understanding the Amyloid disease pathway via statistical mechanics, largely driven by large-scale molecular dynamics simulations. This computational resource request covers many of the simulations we have proposed as parts of recently funded NSF and NIH awards to our research group for basic and applied research in this direction. The proposal covers research in 5 separate major projects in our research group, 1. large-scale replica exchange simulations of the Amyloid Precursor Protein C-terminal fragment C99 in lipid raft-like membranes, 2. replica exchange simulations of C99, alpha- and beta-secretase transmembrane domains in liquid disordered, liquid ordered, and lipid raft-type membrane mixtures and determining the relative free energies of insertion of proteins to these environments via the Energy Representation method, 3. conventional molecular dynamics simulations of complex lipid raft-like lipid bilayer mixtures for characterizing unique lipid-lipid interactions defining these environments that can be determined via combinations of Raman spectroscopy experiments and DFT calculations using lipid conformational clusters sampled in these mixtures, 4. finite size effects of DPC micelle assembly via coarse-grained simulation, large-scale all-atom DPC micelle assembly with and without C99 protein, and replica exchange simulations of micelle-encapsulated C99, and 5. replica exchange simulations of Serum Amyloid A protein. Most of these simulations will be performed alongside ongoing experimental collaboration or in reference to recently published experimental data from our collaborators that have yet to be explained by in-depth molecular simulations.

children.name: TG-MCB130046
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-MCB090163
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-MCB100146
children.project_abstract:
Mechanical phenomena affect nearly every aspect of cellular biology and function, yet the underlying mechanisms of how mechanical forces and biochemical signals interact is not clearly understood. In this proposal, we request for TeraGrid computational facilities to approach cellular mechanotransduction from a computational viewpoint and shed light on two important sub-cellular phenomena in which the role of mechanical factors are decisive: focal adhesion formation and nucleocytoplasmic transport. Individual molecules are suggested to be molecular mechanosensors at focal adhesions. These molecules alter their binding activity upon exposure to external force. We will investigate the validity of this suggestion and evaluate the mechanisms by which single molecules at focal adhesions could act as molecular mechanosensors. 
While our main focus in this proposal will be investigation of focal adhesion formation, we also aim to shed light on nucleocytoplasmic transport across the nuclear pore complex (NPC) using two different approaches: (1) all atomic simulations and (2) coarse-grained modeling. It is suggested that NPC tpr proteins interact with transport factors crm1 and importin-β/α to facilitate the cargo-complex translocation across the NPC. The alleged hydrophobic binding sites, however, are not determined yet. We suggest a thorough molecular dynamic simulation to find those sites. Results from this project could reveal possible mechanisms for facilitated transport. Taking into account the results of all-atomic simulations, we also will develop a coarse-grained model of the whole structure of the NPC to provide a big picture of nucleocytoplasmic transport and find out the specific role of some important factors in active transport, such as FG-repeat density in the pore, active cargo-FG hydrophobic binding affinity, aspect ratio of active cargo, and existing of competing factors within the pore for FG-repeat binding sites. The 9,900,000 SUs we are requesting will let us proceed with these projects and reveal important aspects of each of them at different scales.

children.name: TG-MCB100145
children.project_abstract: A new research allocation of 3.4M SU's is requested for the October 2010-September 2011 period on the AQSL (Abe, Queen Bee, Steele, and Lonestar) Teragrid clusters to perform large scale parallel replica exchange molecular dynamics simulations of macromolecular complexes. The research we plan to perform, which is funded by NIH grant GM30580 to RML, addresses forefront biophysical issues concerning basic mechanisms of molecular recognition in biological systems. The software infrastructure we propose to employ is optimized through parallelism at various levels of the calculation and can make efficient use of the hardware configuration of the AQSL Teragrid clusters. This request follows a start-up allocation of 50,000 SU's (no. MCB100089) which allowed us to port the necessary code and perform benchmarking tests.

children.name: TG-OCE140017
children.project_abstract: The Columbia River Estuary experiences extensive red-colored blooms each year caused by a mixotrophic ciliate of the genus Mesodinium. Even though the blooms are non-toxic, they have a significant impact on the levels of nutrients, light and oxygen in the estuary. Mesodinium displays very particular physiology that makes it one of few planktonic species able to thrive in a highly flushed system: a high growth rate due to its ability to photosynthesize using the photosynthetic organelles of its preys, and complex migrating patterns. With this proposal we will improve an existing Mesodinium model and study the sensitivity of the initiation and decay of the bloom to the river flow magnitude, the timing of the seasonal river flow reduction and the atmospheric forcing. We will also couple the Mesodinium model to a biogeochemical model of the estuary to improve our understanding of the effects that Mesodinium blooms have on the oxygen levels and the production  respiration balance of the estuary. In order to correctly capture the remineralisation processes linked to the Mesodinium bloom decay, a benthic module will be added to the estuary biogeochemical model. We request 754K SU in TACC Stampede and 16 TB of storage in TACC Ranch.

children.name: Thompson_Replication
children.project_abstract:
In spite of continued strong interest in the epigenome, very little is known about the processes that transmit epigenetic marks through multiple rounds of DNA replication and cell division in plants and animals. Because cell-to-cell inheritance is crucial to the function of epigenetic marks, understanding their biology requires an intimate knowledge of DNA replication as well as tools to study events occurring in S phase. In the proposed project, the tools and knowledge of DNA replication developed in the previous PGRP project will be used to characterize epigenome dynamics during S phase in two important model systems – maize and Arabidopsis.
A combination of flow cytometry and in vivo labeling will be used to dissect multiple stages within S phase of cells in suspension culture and in planta. A genome-wide approach and deep sequencing technology will be used to address several fundamental questions about the interplay between DNA replication and epigenetic inheritance.

children.name: iPlant-Collabs
children.project_abstract: The iPlant Collaborative is a successful partnership among UT and several other institutions to provide a comprehensive national cyberinfrastructure. It supports a community science gateway, a REST API, and several joint development, optimization, and scientific sub-projects. This project is intended to coordinate the development and optimization projects, leaving iPlant-Master as a home for the gateway and analysis activities.

children.name: Cancer_Genome
children.project_abstract:
Single base substitutions and genomic rearrangements represent major sources of DNA alterations in cancer. These alterations are often non-random and tend to occur at preferred genomic locations or within certain DNA sequence contexts. We postulate that both the primary DNA sequence as well as secondary structures formed by repeating DNA motifs account in part for the observed sequence-dependent mutation bias. We wish to collect all cancer genome mutation data with the purpose of identifying sequence dependent patterns of mutation by applying bioinformatics and molecular modeling approaches.

Specific aim 1. To test whether sequences prone to form non-B DNA conformations promote chromosomal breaks that lead to gross rearrangements in cancer.

We wish to address the question as to whether DNA sequences with the potential to form alternative (non-B) DNA structures promote chromosomal breaks that lead to gross rearrangements (deletions, duplications, inversions). Towards this end, we have developed comprehensive bioinformatic search criteria to identify all putative non-B DNA-forming sequences, including inverted repeats (cruciform structures), direct repeats (slipped structures), purine.pyrimidine tracts (triplex DNA), alternating purine-pyrimidine runs (left-handed Z-DNA), G-quartets (quadruplex DNA) and phased A-tracts (bent DNA), which have been annotated both in the human genome as well as in some other mammalian genomes. By mapping the locations of chromosomal breaks in cancers with the reference human genome we expect to capture on a broad scale the genomic context of gross rearrangements with respect to the potential of the DNA double helix to adopt more complex secondary structures.

Specific aim 2. To test whether differences in electron distribution along the primary DNA sequence are responsible for sequence preferences in single-base substitutions in cancer.

We wish to address whether sequence-dependent differences within the primary DNA sequence are responsible for variations in single-base substitution patterns among different tumor types. To this end, we are applying high-level theory quantum mechanical calculations to model electron distribution patterns and ionization potentials for all possible tri- and tetra-nucleotide sequence combinations. We then apply these results to single-base substitutions patterns in various cancer types. Our preliminary data on publicly available databases support our postulate that there exists a correlation between predicted sequence-dependent ionization potentials and the fraction of mutated sequences in certain tumor types, such as the lung and melanomas.

Specific aim 3. To test whether cancer mutations that disrupt putative non-B DNA conformations also disrupt the regulatory functions these sequence elements may play.

Most DNA regulatory elements are outside protein-coding sequences. We speculate that a number of cancer mutations may disrupt critical regulatory interactions, either by abolishing binding sites for binding factors or by weakening the stability of secondary structures employed by the cell to perform biological function. We wish to annotate all cancer genome mutations within putative gene regulatory regions and assess their potential to disrupt regulatory protein binding sites and potential non-B DNA conformations. To this end, we are modeling the stability and structures of various DNA conformations by applying molecular dynamics simulations.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

children.name: Daphnia-Evolutionary
children.project_abstract: As a new PI at UT Arlington, I plan to perform population genomic analysis of Daphnia to study various aspects of genome evolution. Particular emphasis will be on the genetic mechanisms for obligately asexual reproduction, genomic regulation of recombination, gene expression changes in response to environmental changes, and tissue-specific epigenetic characterization. This set of projects will involve intensive whole-genome SNP analysis, RNA-seq and Chip-seq analysis using open-source software and custom scripts.

children.name: WESNP
children.project_abstract: Neurologic conditions, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage, pineal cyst, may have a genetic predisposition component. The development of secondary conditions such as neuropathic pain or cerebral edema after spinal cord (SCI) or traumatic brain injury (TBI) may be related to genetic variants. The recovery and/or complications associated with any of these conditions may be related to genetic factors. To better understand the potential genetic variants associated with these conditions, whole exome sequencing will be used to determine whether there are specific genetic factors predictive of, or associated with outcomes. The overall goal of this research is to generate pilot data to identify potential genetic variants in neurosurgical patient groups of similar injuries/conditions with differing phenotypes. The working hypothesis is that genetic factors influence an individual’s propensity to develop these neurological conditions.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston

children.name: TG-MCB190123
children.project_abstract: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a devastating, progressive disease that affects older adults and is associated with high mortality, resulting in death 3-5 years after diagnosis. Rare damaging variants in genes encoding surfactant protein production are linked to inherited forms of pulmonary fibrosis and help inform pathogenesis of disease. Leveraging CRISPR-Cas9, we have generated a mouse model of the hSftpa2 p.Gly231Val (G231V) mutation which was implicated with inherited pulmonary fibrosis in a large family. We propose using single cell RNA sequencing to highlight unique cellular contributions to pulmonary fibrosis in this mouse model. Using computing resources from Stampede2 compute nodes, we hope to analyze complex transcriptomic data to untangle and interpret gene expression profiles from total lung samples of homozygous and wild type mice.

children.name: Ceniklab-Startup
children.project_abstract:
We will use this project for: 
1) getting ourselves familiar with TACC
2) Doing some initial data processing and management
3) Train students in the lab

children.name: Polyploidy
children.project_abstract: Polyploidy is an evolutionary innovation in many plants and some animals. Understanding how polyploid and hybrid crops grow better than the parents will generate a direct impact in agriculture, the environment, food security, renewable energy, and human health.  Most important crops including wheat and cotton are allopolyploid, and many others such as maize (an ancient polyploid) are grown as hybrids.  Hybrids are formed by mating with different strains, varieties or species. An allopolyploid such as wheat or African clawed frog is formed by hybridizing with two or more species followed by chromosome doubling, whereas an autopolyploid such as potato or salmon results from genome duplication within the same species.  Many organisms that behave as diploid are actually paleopolyploid (ancient polyploid) and overtime become diploidized, as shown in the sequenced genomes of yeast, Arabidopsis poplar tree, grapevine, maize, and soybean.  Of flowering plants, over 70% may be recent polyploids of which >75% are allopolyploids. In this project, we will use genomic and computational tools to elucidate changes in gene expression in Arabidopsis allopolyploids and hybrids, maize and sorghum hybrids, as well as to annotate and compare the genomes of cultivated allotetraploid cotton and its extant diploid progenitors.
children.pi_institution: Center for Computational Biology and Bioinformatics

children.name: TG-AST180036
children.project_abstract: The research presented in this proposal addresses a long-standing problem in extragalactic astrophysics, namely the mismatch between the ubiquity of fast moving, cold gas in and around various types of galaxies throughout cosmic time, and basic hydrodynamical theory which predicts that cold gas will be destroyed before it can be accelerated by ram pressure (such a provided by supernovae feedback in galaxies). Our recent results indicate that we can potentially solve that puzzle in a region of parameter space which allows for the re-formation of the cold gas faster than its destruction through hydrodynamical instabilities. However, thus far we could merely show that this parameter space exists. In the proposed research, we want to bridge the gap to observations, and extend our work to realistic setups which include a non-homogeneous wind model, magnetic fields, and anisotropic thermal conduction. Each of these processes are present in galactic environments and will influence the outcome substantially, and are thus crucial to include in order to assess if this effect can indeed solve the "entrainment problem", and to compare our findings to observations.

children.name: TG-AST110035
children.project_abstract: In this allocation proposal we request computing time and storage space on XSEDE resources, principally Stampede and Gordon to improve the methods currently used to generate multimass cosmological initial conditions and reduce their cost. This will be mainly done by doing a careful analysis of different Lagrange volume definitions used to build them following Oorbe et al. (2013) work. We also aim to provide publicly available high resolution ICs for the AGORA collaboration framework (Kim et al., 2013). Our simulations will be performed with the mature public codes, GADGET-3, an TreePM-SPH code, and ENZO, an AMR hybrid code, designed to accurately follow the physical processes that are relevant at galactic scales. To generate the cosmological initial conditions we will make use of the MUSIC software package. We have performed several tests for all this software on our own computational resources and on the XSEDE resources. Based on these experiments our request of 6.1M SUs will guarantee the accomplishment of the simulations and its scientific goal.

children.name: TG-AST120025
children.project_abstract:
We request computing time on the XSEDE resources to perform high-resolution, cosmological simulations of galaxy formation which will resolve the interstellar medium (ISM) physics with un- precedented realism. In our new physical model, the ISM is explicitly resolved into dense molecular clouds. Star formation is confined to these high-density regions and, as it proceeds, injects large quantities of energy and momentum into the surrounding medium via stellar feedback. This stellar feedback is critical to produce realistic galaxies and to generate powerful galactic winds. These galactic winds also have important effects on the circum-galactic and intergalactic media (CGM, IGM), and understanding them is a key frontier.
For the first time, we incorporate all the important stellar feedback mechanisms (radiation pressure in the ultra-violet, optical, and infrared; stellar winds; supernova explosions of Types I & II; and photoionization heating in HII regions) in a self-consistent manner. The combination of resolved, clumpy ISM and positive reinforcement of different feedback mechanisms produce powerful galactic winds with properties consistent with observations without ad hoc prescriptions, which previous simulations typically have had to incorporate.
For this initial study, our proposed simulations concentrate on the high-redshift Universe. This regime, of intense observational focus, is less computational expensive and will therefore allow us to simulate a range of galaxies (from dwarfs to massive disks) to develop a systematic understanding of the scale-dependent physics.
Thanks to their novelty and realism, the proposed set of simulations will be analyzed to address a wide array of timely scientific questions. We will study the evolution of the galactic ISM, galaxy growth and its self-regulation via galactic winds, the interaction of infalling material with galactic outflows, metal dispersion in the CGM and IGM, as well as the thermal, kinematic, and ionizing effects of galaxies on their surroundings. XSEDE resources provide the computational power necessary to perform our simulations, which have outgrown our local computing resources. We will use the well-tested smooth particle hydrodynamics (SPH) code Gadget-3, which we significantly expanded to implement more realistic cooling, star formation, and feedback modules (also verified in a series of recent papers describing them).
We have successfully performed multiple medium-sized runs using the production version of the code on a university-based computing cluster and have successfully compiled and run basic scaling tests with the same version of the code on Ranger at TACC. This enabled us to estimate runtime requirements for our proposed simulations, totaling 1.76 million SUs.

children.name: Dark-Matter-Warms-Up
children.project_abstract:
Observations on a variety of scales, from galaxies to large-scale structure, indicate that the dominant component of matter in the Universe does not interact via electromagnetism. This dark matter is generally assumed to be "cold" in the sense that it has negligible thermal velocity in the early Universe; this assumption is supported by virtually all observations of dark matter. At the smallest scales we can probe observationally, however, discrepancies have emerged. These scales are tested by the abundance and structure of dwarf galaxies, and many observations indicate less structure than would naively be expected in cold dark matter models. This may be an indication of a small but non-zero free-streaming length for dark matter.

We propose to run a suite of simulations of dwarf galaxies under the assumption that dark matter is "warm". The simulations will include two versions: dark-matter-only simulations, where the structure of the dwarf galaxy hosts will only be set by dark matter physics, and full simulations with galaxy formation physics, which can also modify the dark matter structure. Our adopted galaxy formation physics models are state-of-the-art and being used in multiple related projects, providing strong legacy value for these simulations. Additionally, we have already performed identical simulations of the very same dwarf galaxies in the Cold Dark Matter model, meaning we will be able to directly compare our results to existing simulations in the standard cosmology. Our results will establish whether Warm Dark Matter is a viable alternative to the standard Cold Dark Matter model on the scale of dwarf galaxies, which is the regime where Cold Dark Matter may show discrepancies with observations.

children.name: TG-AST130007
children.project_abstract: We propose to run a set of hydrodynamic cosmological simulations that include a complete treatment of galaxy formation physics together with Self-Interacting Dark Matter (SIDM). With them we will search for a solution to the discrepancy between the observed dark matter central densities in galaxies and galaxy clusters, and those predicted by our standard model of cosmological structure formation. For this we will explore the phenomenological consequences of two qualitatively different classes of solutions: self-interacting dark matter and stellar feedback. Our work will contribute to our understanding on how baryons transform the central structure of dark matter halos, how self-interacting dark matter affects galaxy formation, and what are the resulting central densities of dark matter halos when self-interacting dark matter acts together with baryonic processes. We will provide the best constraints available on how strong can dark matter self-interact, and demonstrate if SIDM is a viable solution to the small scale problems that challenge our standard CDM paradigm.

children.name: TG-AST120046
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: Hobby-Eberly-Telesco
children.project_abstract: The Hobby-Eberly Telescope Dark Energy Experiment will measure the expansion rate of the universe as it was 9 billion years ago. This project includes a significant upgrade to the HET and a substantial observing program. It is one of the few premier observing programs in the world, and it is led by the University of Texas. The total amount of data it will generate is around 10 Pb. We hope to use TACC facilities to host and analyze the data. We will explore aspects for big data analysis from storage to access to new statistical and visualization tools.

children.name: lensing2
children.project_abstract: The most intense star formation that ever occurred in the universe was hosted by galaxies in the first few billion years after the Big Bang, heavily obscured by cosmic "dust" which blocks direct viewing of the young, forming stars. Instead, astronomers observe these galaxies using radio telescopes such as the Very Large Array in New Mexico and the ALMA telescope in Chile. My work utilizes natural "cosmic microscopes" - taking advantage of intervening foreground galaxies between us and the more distant dusty galaxies, which magnify our view of the background galaxies in a process called gravitational lensing. In order to understand the intrinsic properties of the background galaxies, though, we must model the effects of this lensing. This is computationally difficult for data from the telescopes listed above, because they measure the Fourier transform of the sky instead of a direct image of it, and each observational dataset contains millions of observables. I have written advanced codes to do this modeling.  For the startup portion of this project over the past months, I got the codes to run on TACC's stampede2 system and ran some test analyses. I am now ready to continue this work under a standard research allocation.

children.name: TG-AST140023
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-PHY180057
children.project_abstract:
While neutrino oscillation experiments have demonstrated that neutrinos have small, nonzero masses, resulting in the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physics, much remains unknown about their properties and decay modes. One potential decay mode â?? neutrinoless double beta decay (0Î½Î²Î²) â?? is a particularly interesting target of current experimental searches, since its observation would imply that the neutrino is a Majorana particle, demonstrate that lepton number conservation is violated in nature and thus provide a possible mechanism for baryogenesis in the early universe, and give further constraints on the neutrino masses and mixing angles. Relating experimental constraints on 0Î½Î²Î² decay rates to the neutrino masses, however, requires theoretical input in the form of nuclear matrix elements which remain difficult to calculate reliably. Current nuclear model calculations of the needed matrix elements for a particular nuclei typically differ by 100% or more [1], and continued progress toward using experimental measurements to constrain particular models of neutrinoless double beta decay will require improving this situation.

In principle, lattice QCD allows for entirely ab-initio calculations of the relevant nuclear matrix elements with complete control over systematic errors. First results for the long-distance contributions to the neutrinoful double beta decay process nn â?? ppeeÎ½Î½ and the leading order short-distance contributions to 0Î½Î²Î² in chiral perturbation theory have been recently computed in Refs. [2] and [3] by the NPLQCD and CalLat collaborations, respectively. NPLQCD has since developed code based on the Columbia Physics System (CPS) [4] and Bagel Fermion Sparse Matrix Library (BFM) [5] code bases for computing 0Î½Î²Î² decay matrix elements, and has performed an initial exploratory calculation of the simplest such process Ï? â?? Ï?ee described in Ref. [6]. We are currently running a complete calculation of the long-distance and short-distance contributions to the 0Î½Î²Î² decay amplitude for Ï? â?? Ï?ee on the locally available Blue Gene/Q supercomputer at Brookhaven National Lab, which will be permanently decommissioned in January.

An XSEDE startup allocation will allow us to port this code to the Intel Knights Landing platform and profile its performance. Existing high-performance KNL code implemented in the Grid physics library [7] can be used in place of our existing BFM code optimized for the BG/Q
platform, and we will also explore replacing our current FFT routines which use the FFTW MPI library with the optimized Intel Math Kernel Library FFT routines. We will then use Stampede to finish our Ï? â?? Ï?ee calculation if needed, and begin to explore computing matrix elements of processes with baryonic and nuclear initial and final states --- such as the fundamental, quark-level decay nn â?? ppee which occurs inside the nucleus --- which can then be related to matrix elements of large nuclei used in 0Î½Î²Î² experiments through many-body effective field theory techniques. These are challenging but important calculations that will require large-scale resources like those available through XSEDE, and we intend to use the Startup Allocation to prepare a request for a Research Allocation in the next cycle.

References:
[1] A. Giuliani and A. Poves, â??Neutrinoless Double-Beta Decayâ?, Adv. High Energy Phys. 2012, 857016 (2012).
