The JHU-TDC (http://turbulence.pha.jhu.edu/) currently contains 27 TB of data for forced isotropic turbulence and 56 TB of data for forced magneto-hydrodynamic turbulence. All of these data are made publicly available through web services in which clients can retrieve spatio-temporal data consisting of the primitive variables and also additional data such as gradients, particle paths, etc.\ which are evaluated in-situ at the database server. Spatial and temporal interpolation functions are implemented to provide continuous treatment of the discrete fields. We will then utilize the JHU-TDC service to study stress distributions and small-scale structures near the wall. To be specific, we want to compare the simulations with recent experimental work that found two types of buffer layer structures i.e., a pair of counter rotating vortices and multiple stream-wise vortices. Both of these structures are found to correspond to strong wall stress events. The database enables us to visualize the pre-history of flow structures by being able to follow the evolution backwards in time. We require significant resources to run the simulations at a friction-velocity based Reynolds number of $1000$, which requires a grid of $2048\times512\times1536$ grid cells. We plan to use XSEDE facilities to perform such a simulation, which will require $\sim 10^5$ time-steps at the aforementioned resolution and use MPI-DB, a parallel database service developed at Johns Hopkins, to create the database.

Both the wind energy and channel flow database projects have been funded by corresponding NSF grants, and therefore have already undergone peer-review processes.

children.name: Capstone-Wilkes
children.project_abstract: This project is for Hunter Wilkes senior Capstone Project entitled “Continental U.S. mesocyclone development in future IPCC scenarios”.  The project involves using the NCAR WRF model and running a series of high-resolution (3-km) convection permitting model simulations to improve our understanding of the development of severe storms of the U.S., and how such storms may change in the future under global warming.

children.name: TG-ATM170028
children.project_abstract:
Accurate prediction of wind farm performance under realistic conditions is the current challenge in wind energy research. Large-eddy simulations (LES) has been used for process-scale simulations under idealized conditions, such as fixed wind speed and direction, and constant static stability. It is difficult to compare results of such idealized simulations with observations because atmospheric conditions are dynamically evolving in time, due to the diurnal variation. Another source for dichotomy between observations and simulations is that computational studies are very often carried out for a single isolated turbine, or for infinitely-large wind farms leading to the fully-developed wind-turbine array boundary layer. Field observations, however, are for large but finite-sized wind farms, where the number of turbines is at most of the order of a few hundreds. 

The primary aim of this work is to study the performance of a large, finite-sized wind farm under realistic atmospheric forcing using LES. The Firewheel Wind Energy Complex (FWEC) will serve as the primary testbed. This wind farm which is currently under development on the Oklahoma-Texas border is projected to be one of the largest wind farms in the world with over 1200 horizontal axis wind turbines (HAWTs) and will serve as a primary energy source for the Plains and Eastern Clean Line, a new concept for long-distance, high-voltage DC transmission. Our partners in this project, Map Royalty, Inc. are leading the development at the FWEC, and have provided us with historical meteorological data from that site. A computational allocation to perform numerical simulations, informed by the available historical meteorological data, at unprecedented resolutions, would be a unique opportunity to study realistic flow physics of the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) and the wind farm.

children.name: TG-AST140008
children.project_abstract: We will be performing simulations of the formation and collapse of molecular clouds.  The formation will be through the thermal instability of warm (T=5000 K) atomic gas.  We will measure the distribution of cloud properties, discriminate between a variety of star formation models, and compare the magnetic field strengths of these clouds to recent observations using synthetic spectra.  The simulations will use the divergence-free MHD module in the adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) code Enzo.

children.name: TG-AST130004
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: Doping-effects-on-th
BattPFM_PROD
children.project_abstract: Electrode materials in advanced batteries often undergo phase transformations during charge and discharge processes. Under the large electrochemical driving forces inherent to practical use, they frequently exhibit unique phase transition behavior not seen in other systems. An improved understanding of phase transformation pathways in electrode materials upon electrochemical cycling will lead to new materials design concepts and electrochemical duty cycle management strategy that improve capacity utilization and extend battery life. In this project we aim to obtain a fundamental understanding of phase transformation processes in important battery electrode materials with the help of high-performance computing. Mesoscale phase-field simulations will be employed as the main tool for the study. We will develop parallel MPI code to run simulations on TACC clusters. The code will utilize numerical packages such as Petsc, FFTW and Hypre that are available on TACC. Both small-to-medium (50-200 cores) and large-size (>1000 cores) simulations are planned for systems with single or multiple electrodes particles. Initial model materials include lithium transition metal olivine cathode and silicon anode, and may be extended to additional systems at the later stage of the project. Output from the simulations will be compared against in-situ X-ray diffraction and transmission microscopy experiments to explain the phase transformation phenomena in the selected systems and shed light on potential ways to further improve their performance.

children.name: TG-AST130002
children.project_abstract:
Our group requests a total of 6.5e6 SUs on the TACC machine Stampede to 
conduct global numerical simulations of astrophysical accretion disks.  
We will use the well-tested magnetohydrodynamic code  Athena to carry out these simulations. 
The project is separated into three parts:

We will carry out global MHD simulations to study dust particle dynamics in turbulent protoplanetary disks using our newly developed particle module in Athena. 
 We will study how dust concentrates in turbulence, which is crucial for planetesimal and planet formation.  This study will also make detailed observational predictions  for current telescopes. 

We will add planets in above simulations to study how planets interact with turbulent disks and dust particles in these disks, which is essential for understanding the survivability and growth of young planets.

We will study accretion disks around the white dwarf in interacting close binary system. By comparing with existing observations over past 20 years, such study will enable us to directly constrain accretion physics. 

We propose to run 5 calculations in total. We have already run low resolution studies to explore 
parameter space, and we request XSEDE resources only to run a small number of resolved models that will elucidate the physics of disks in each regime.
Finally, we request 2.5e3 GB of archival storage on the TACC Ranch system.
To visualize the data, we request 2e4 SUs on the TACC machine Maverick.

Funding for the proposed research will be provided by a NASA Hubble Fellowship (awarded to the PI),
the National Science Foundation (AST-0908269) and Princeton University. The time requested is essential for our proposed research since it is the only time requested from our accretion disk group at Princeton university this year.

children.name: TG-AST120060
children.project_abstract:
Supersonic collimated outflows have been observed emanating from Young Stel- lar Objects, Proto-Planetary Nebulae (PPN) and other astrophysical objects. Understanding the physics of these jets is a key challenge in plasma astro- physics, for they are a powerful natural mechanisms of energy transport.
One paradigm to explain the formation of jets in PPN, in particular, is that of a binary stellar system in which material from the wind of an AGB star is gravitationally pulled onto an intermediate-mass companion. A hot magnetized rapidly rotating plasma disk will be formed about the companion star. The rotational and magnetic energy of this disk will then lead to the launch and collimation of jets. Several fundamental questions remain open in this scenario however. In particular which kinds binaries, (i.e. for which separations and mass ratios), form stable accretion disks? Do all disks form jets? What affects the stability of disk driven jets?
Based on novel results obtained with our previous start-up XSEDE allocation (TG-AST120029) we propose to carry out a series of three-dimensional Adaptive Mesh Refinement parallel numerical simulations to study the formation, struc- ture and stability, and observational implications, of interacting stellar binaries. This will include (1) accretion from the primary AGB wind onto a secondary star and (2) launch and propagation of strongly magnetized jets. Our compu- tations will be performed with higher resolution and longer time-scales than attempted in previous studies and we will be using our locally developed, well tested code AstroBEAR 2.0 for the simulations. Binary-formed accretion disks will be investigated for stellar separations of 10, 20, 30, 40astronomical units and for mass ratios of 1.5. We will also study strongly magnetized jets in both adiabatic and cooling regimes using toroidal-to-poloidal magnetic component ratios of .1, 1, 10, 100.
While we are in full production mode with AstroBEAR 2.0 the numerical resources of the XSEDE that we are requesting are needed to make further progress on unraveling the fundamental questions concerning interacting bina- ries and their disks/outflows. To achieve this goal we request the support of 4 million SUs on Kraken at NICS and 4 million SUs on Ranger at TACC.

children.name: Scattering-Propertie
children.project_abstract: We study the scattering properties of nanoscale systems,  including models of  small molecules and two dimensional condensed matter systems. This gives of information about quasibound states and decay processes in such systems.

children.name: TG-PHY170047
children.project_abstract: The research allocation request is for the intensive computational work needed for a recently awarded research grant number 1714159, "Computational Atomic Laboratory Astrophysics for Stellar and Nebular Spectral Diagnostics," from the Galactic Astronomy Program of the US National Science Foundation where the details of the research objectives, intellectual merit, and broader impacts of the proposed work have been described. The primary research objective is to minimize the uncertainties in radiative and collision atomic data for the iron-peak ions using novel computational methodologies and computer codes. The electron and photon interactions with iron-peak ions will be computed using the state-of-the-art B-spline Breit-Pauli R-matrix (BSR) computer codes. Accurate description of complicated atomic structure with almost half-filled 3$d$ shell is the key to the reliable and accurate computation of radiative transition and collision rates. The combination of B-spline box-based multichannel and multiconfiguration Hartree-Fock (MCHF) computational approaches has proven to be very effective in achieving high accuracy in the recent computation of atomic scattering parameters for atomic oxygen and Fe$^{8+}$ ion. Our research allocation request is based on the computation of atomic data for oxygen and some preliminary non-relativistic test calculation for Fe$^+$ using XSEDE allocated resources on the LSU SuperMIC and TACC Stampede. We request 40,000 node hours on Stampede 2 and 500,000 service units on SuperMIC to compute transition rates and electron excitation collision rates of the Fe$^+$ ion. XSEDE resources are essential for us to succeed in this work. The reliable and accurate atomic parameters for Fe$^+$ ion are important to the analysis and interpretation of the spectra of stellar and nebular objects. The computed atomic data will be deposited in publicly available CLOUDY and CHIANTI databases for the easy access to the Astrophysics community.

children.name: TG-PHY160006
children.project_abstract:
Microthrusters are a class of engines used primarily for station keeping and orbit correction maneuvers. Our work relates to predicting the operations of electrospray micro thruster engines, which use ionic liquids (ILs) in the presence of an applied electric field to generate thrust using Taylor cone. Taylor cone are generated by IL in a capillary when a strong electric field is applied between the tip of the capillary and an extractor plate. Even though Taylor cone are a widely known and have wide range of applications, the process of formation and physics behind Taylor cone is still not well understood. Molecular dynamics method (MD) allows us to understand the underlying electro-chemical interactions at an atomic level, in the formation and emission from the Taylor cone.
   MD methods scale on the order of number of atoms present in the system. Electrospray simulations require a large number of molecules and long simulation times due to the non-equilibrium nature of these simulations. We have proposed to use and successfully developed coarse grained (CG) model, which aim to reduce the number of atoms required to represent the system. This allows us to run large MD simulations with high computational efficiency. Using the `startup' allocation awarded to us, we developed and demonstrated the use of CG model of Ethylammonium Nitrate (EAN).
   We are requesting `research' allocation for 522,240 SUs to perform electrospray simulations coupled with Poisson solver. Space charge broadening is a phenomena observed in electrospray emission, where the ions/ion agrregates have a tendency to form an over expanded jet. This behavior is not captured entirely using MD and so we propose to couple our MD simulations with Poisson solver, where depending on the position of the charged species, updated using MD, Poisson's equation will be solved to generate an electric field which is not constant throughout the domain. In the next time step, the electric field predicted by Poisson solver will used to calculate the forces on the atoms and their corresponding change in position using MD.

children.name: TG-CHE140109
children.project_abstract:
Heterogeneous catalysts improve the efficiency of chemical transformations and are used for the production of fuels, chemicals, and the abatement of harmful emissions. Modern catalysis exists for about 100 years, but catalyst design and development remains by and large a time-consuming experimental trial-and-error process. The discovery of density functional theory (DFT) and the availability of large computational resources have already started to have a significant impact on our understanding of catalysis, and more importantly, they become increasingly applicable for the in silico design of new catalytic materials. The most successful approach for the identification of novel catalysts is known as computational catalyst screening, which encompasses three main steps: (i) the identification of the dominant reaction mechanism and the key reaction intermediates; (ii) the determination of a small set of catalytic reactivity descriptors that can predict reactivity and selectivity trends; and (iii) the calculation of these reactivity descriptors on new catalysts.
In the PIs group at the University of Houston (UH) we apply computational catalysis techniques, primarily DFT, to study catalytic process that enable the more efficient use of natural resources. This includes the utilization of abundant natural gas and biomass as fuel and feedstock for the production of valuable chemicals. The use of different fuels in vehicles, e.g. natural gas engines, also requires novel catalytic converters for emissions aftertreatment. Our group is very active in studying such catalysts and we collaborate closely with experimental groups at UH and elsewhere.

children.name: Ras
children.project_abstract:
The signaling protein Ras, which propagates a variety of signal transduction cascades important in cell division, cell survival, and cell death, conducts all of its biological function through protein-protein interactions, and mutations of Ras that alter these interactions are associated with high incidence of human cancerous tumor growth. Understanding the molecular-level mechanisms that are responsible for the formation of an interface between Ras and other proteins, such as the downstream effector Ral, and in particular how oncogenic mutations of Ras alter the function of these interfaces, will provide new insight into the mechanism of Ras in tumor initiation and growth, and new strategies for successful drug design. Our group uses spectroscopic methods to measure electrostatic fields directly at the protein-protein interface. We aim to connect our experimental measurements with detailed atomistic models of the Ras-Ral interface and validate that connection through calculated electric fields.

However, in order to calculate meaningful electric fields, the phase space distribution of protein and solvent degrees of freedom generally and the probe orientation specifically must be sufficiently sampled. Therefore, molecular dynamics simulations of the monomeric probe molecule alone and with its binding partner must be used to sample from the partition function most closely reflecting experimental conditions. Because there are tens of thousands of degrees of freedom for Ral and more than 100,000 for the Ras-Ral complex, sufficient sampling requires significant computational resources.

However, there are many points of failure which may lead to poor calculations. For instance, the effect of force fields on probe orientational distributions is unknown, so several point charge and polarizable force fields must be tested to determine which lead to the most accurate electrostatic fields. Other factors including temperature (and the thermostat used to maintain that temperature), pressure, ionic strength, pH, methods for computing long-range forces, solvent model, initial conditions, modeling of protein structure for those residues without experimental coordinates, and many others add further complexity to the calculation.

We are requesting time on Stampede specifically to obtain good thiocyanate probe orientational distributions for Ral and the Ras-Ral complex for a single set of conditions: temperature, volume, force field, long-range force treatment, ionic strength and pH. Time on Ranger will allow us to explore whether varying these parameters can lead to electrostatic characteristics are better able to retrospectively and prospectively predict experimental results.

children.name: TG-CHE140072
children.project_abstract: The PI requests computing time on Stampede of XSEDE resources to advance currently DOE funded research projects about computational design of low cost yet high performance catalysts for energy conversion technologies such as proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). (1) The first project involves computational study of cost-effective transition metal nitrogen graphene nonprecious metal (TM-N-C) catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) occurring at the cathode of a PEMFC. First-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations will be performed to elucidate the chemical nature of active sites, investigate the pathway of ORR, identify the performance controlling reaction steps, and predict the rate of ORR on this class of catalysts. Furthermore, we aim to find electronic descriptor correlating with the ORR activity on TM-N-C catalysts.( 2) The second project focuses on the computational design of highly active Pt alloy catalysts for methanol (CH3OH) electrooxidation reaction, the reaction that occurs at the anode of a DMFC. We will investigate the pathway of CH3OH electrooxidation reaction on the (111) facet of a series of Pt-based alloy catalysts. DFT calculations will be performed to obtain the free energy of adsorption of all chemical species, and heats of reaction and activation energies of all possible elementary chemical reactions in CH3OH oxidation. The calculated energetics (free energy of adsorption, heats of reactions, and activation energies) on Pt alloy catalysts will be used to search the best performing Pt alloy catalysts for CH3OH oxidation. Moreover, we will find an electronic descriptor of Pt alloy catalysts correlating with the activity of Pt alloys for CH3OH oxidation.

children.name: TG-EAR080022N
children.project_abstract: The Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics (CIG), an NSF center, develops and maintains open-source geodynamics software in support of the NSF-supported Earth science community. The goal of CIGs efforts is to provide software that will help researchers and students address important unsolved problems in geophysics, including problems in mantle dynamics, crustal and lithospheric dynamics on both million-year and earthquake time-scales, and seismic wave propagation. CIG engaged in these activities under an MRAC and requested to upgrade to an LRAC in January 2008, as the positive response from the community has been consuming its present TeraGrid allocation at a substantially higher rate than anticipated. This proposal justification will answer questions and address issues raised by the LRAC Review Board. In the previously submitted LRAC application, CIG proposed to continue to promote four geodynamics codes through operation and further development of its science gateway and by pre-installing more codes in TeraGrids Community Software Area. The Seismology Science Gateway, already deployed, features SPECFEM3D_GLOBE, a spectral-element code that simulates global and regional (continental-scale) seismic wave propagation; SPECFEM3D, which simulates southern California seismic wave propagation, is a planned future addition. Three CIG finite-element codes (CitcomS, Gale, and PyLith) are all state-of-the art and scale well on a variety of TeraGrid platforms. Using a powerful, yet simplified interface that will run and benchmark these applications via a web browser, we hope to increase the ability of the Earth Sciences community to access TeraGrid resources. A benchmarking tool, the CIG Model Analyzer (Cigma), will also be offered as a web service. An allocation is requested for four activities: (1) operation and continued development of the science gateway, (2) benchmarking, (3) workshops and training sessions, and (4) nurturing new users on the TeraGrid using CIG software.

children.name: A-ch511
children.project_abstract:
This research work is focus on investigation of the relationship between microstructure and physical properties of the porous materials, such as an oil bearing rock, a piece of paper, or a polymer composite. Discovering the accurate relationship is a long standing problem of theoretical and practical interest in many fields of technology: 1) Build virtual porous materials numerically on the computer. A detailed charateristics of the micriostructure can be obtained; 2) Develop the sophisticated algorithm to simulate the single phase flow through the porous materials, and calculate its transport properties; 3) Develop new algorithm to simulate 
the electrical conducticion of the materials.

children.name: TG-MCA03S012
children.project_abstract:
The SCEC Community Modeling Environment (SCEC/CME) collaboration, an inter-disciplinary research group from the Southern California Earthquake Center (SCEC), the San Diego Supercomputer Center, Carnegie Mellon University, and USC Information Sciences Institute, requests computational time and storage resources in support of a large-scale geophysical research program in earthquake system science. The SCEC/ CME collaboration is a highly skilled and experienced group of geoscientists, and computer science and computational science researchers, with many years of high performance computing, data management, and scientific workflow expertise.

The simulation-based research program outlined in this request will be performed as part of the NSF-funded SCEC Project titled A Petascale Cyber-facility for Physics-Based Seismic Hazard Analysis (PetaSHA). The PetaSHA project is a multi-year program of simulation-based scientific research that builds up scientific capabilities and computational capabilities through a series of increasingly challenging physics-based simulations. 

The PetaSHA project plan outlines a series of computationally challenging milestone simulations that advance the SCEC geophysics research program. In this proposal, we request time to develop, validate, and perform a number of the PetaSHA milestone simulations. The proposed simulations are an inter-related set of simulations that include dynamic rupture simulations, large scale earthquake wave propagation simulations, verification and validation simulations, and
ensemble earthquake wave propagation simulations to develop probabilistic seismic hazard curves.

The allocation will support research to be performed under an NSF grant (EAR-0623704) A Petascale Cyber-facility for Physics-Based Seismic Hazard Analysis (PetaSHA). The proposed research also supports the core SCEC research program which is funded by NSF Cooperative Agreement EAR-0106924 and USGS Cooperative Agreement 02HQAG0008.

children.name: STAR-Technip
children.project_abstract: Numerical wave tank simulations to validate of Euler-Overlay Method

children.name: TG-GEO170003
children.project_abstract:
Knowledge of the physical and chemical states of the Earthâ??s rocky mantle is crucial to our understanding of various geological processes, such as plate tectonics, global heat loss, geochemical cycling, and the processes that led to the development of our planetâ??s unique habitat. Seismological and geochemical observations provide insights into the physics and chemistry of the Earthâ??s interior. However, only by comparing mineral physics data (physical properties) with the seismological observations can we disentangle the thermal state of the deep Earth from its chemistry. Conventionally, as a first order approximation, the Earthâ??s mantle is thought to be composed of a homogenous pyrolite. But, in reality, this region is far from being homogeneous. The distinct trace element signatures in mid ocean ridge and ocean island basalts reveal the heterogeneity in the Earthâ??s mantle. Although the scale of the heterogeneity is unknown, it is likely that large regions of the mantle are composed of a depleted harzburgite and enriched crustal fractions. We have limited knowledge of the thermodynamics and physical properties of mineral phases in these subducted crusts at high pressures.
We propose to examine the elasticity of hollandite along a ternary system- [(K,Na)(1-x)CaxAl(1+x)Si(3-x)O8] where, 0<x<1. We will explore the pressure dependence (0-150 GPa) of the ferroelastic transition between hollandite I and hollandite-II. We will explore the effect of iron on the elasticity of hollandite. In particular, how iron spin pairing transition couples with the ferroelastic transition. Finally we will also explore the effect of hydrogen defect on the structure and elasticity of hollandite. We will integrate our understanding of elasticity of hollandite with other major phases such as stishovite and majorite garnet to constrain the elasticit signatures of the deeply subducted continental crust in the Earthâ??s mantle.

children.name: TG-AST190019
children.project_abstract: We propose to use the Stampede2 supercomputer to run global galaxy simulations of thermally and cosmic ray driven outflows from dwarf galaxies, specifically the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds (LMC and SMC), two dwarf satellite galaxies of the Milky Way exhibiting large-scale supernova-driven outflows. This work builds off our pilot study (Bustard et al. 2018) run on Stampede2 under a previous start-up allocation (TG-AST170033; PI: Chad Bustard,Co-PI: Ellen Zweibel). In this work, we used the FLASH magnetohydrodynamics code to simulate outflows from the LMC during it's infall through the Milky Way halo, and we found the interaction between weak "fountain" flows and the headwind experienced by the LMC to be important in ultimately expelling gas. Our proposed work will probe the additional effects of magnetic fields and cosmic rays, some of the most highly energetic particles in the universe, including a novel implementation of the so-called cosmic ray streaming instability. This extremely sub-grid interaction between charged cosmic ray particles and plasma waves has been approximated in a fluid treatment and can have large-scale effects on galaxy evolution. With these additions to our model, we will undertake a study of cosmic ray and thermally driven outflows from the LMC and SMC, varying key parameters such as method of cosmic ray transport, initial magnetic field strength,  and  level  of  supernova  clustering.  We  will  then  create  synthetic  observations  using extensively tested visualization toolkits,  and we will compare these directly to the wealth of observational data on the Magellanic System. By using the Clouds, two of the most well-studied extra-galactic objects in the Universe, as test-beds for outflow launching, we can, for the first time, connect resolved star formation histories and detailed observations of galaxies to their supernova-driven expulsions. Using observational constraints on the magnetic field strength, cosmic ray population, star cluster masses, etc., we can probe what works and what doesn't to launch the observed outflows. This is of vital importance to understanding how galaxies self-regulate their star formation by transferring gas to the intergalactic medium, and it will provide a useful case-study for dwarf galaxy evolution in general.

children.name: TG-AST190018
children.project_abstract:
Stars are the fundamental units of astrophysics and their formation is a key process that influences the evolution of galaxies, planets, and the development of life. Understanding how stars form is crucial even for seemingly unconnected fields of astronomy, Their formation includes a wide range of physical phenomena: both super- and subsonic turbulence, magnetic fields, weakly ionized plasmas, continuum and line radiative processes compounded by complex chemical processes and gravity, making the problem of star formation extremely complex. The difficulty is further compounded by the wide dynamic range of the problem: the process of star formation is initiated in giant molecular clouds (GMCs), which are 9 orders of magnitude larger than the protostars and stars that form in the end. 

Our goal is to understand the roles turbulence, magnetic fields, radiative feedback, outflows and the local environment play in star formation, on scales from individual stars and protostars to GMCs. The proposed simulations will be used to address the following questions:
1) What physical mechanisms are responsible for setting the masses of individual stars? 
2) How do different feedback mechanisms (e.g., radiation, outflows) interact to regulate star formation in GMCs? 
3) What determines the physical properties of star clusters that form in a given environment? How do the properties of the progenitor cloud affect the mass, size, and density profile of the resulting star clusters? 

Unlike previous studies that were confined to a small region of a GMC, the simulations we propose here will provide a self-consistent picture of a cloud disrupted by long-range feedback (e.g., winds and radiation from O-stars, supernovae). We propose a series of runs with progressively more complicated physics: starting from pure isothermal collapse, then adding magnetic fields, cooling physics, dust, protostellar heating and outflows and main sequence stellar feedback.This step-by-step approach will allow us to identify the role of each physical process in star formation in a self-consistent framework for the first time.

children.name: Galaxy-SHELA-HETDEX
children.project_abstract: A fundamental question in astronomy is how galaxies build and assemble their stars and dark matter halos across different environments. In the nearby Universe, galaxy properties vary dramatically as a function of both stellar mass and environment, but it is unknown when or how these differences were created.  To address this problem, one must target the critical epoch about 10 to 12 billion years in the past (redshifts between 1.9 and 3.5), when massive galaxies assembled, cosmic star-formation and black-hole accretion peaked, and the largest proto-clusters collapsed. Until now, systematic studies of this epoch have been hampered by a lack of data:  while a number of programs have the requisite deep imaging and  spectroscopy, none come close to sampling the full range of galactic environments, from the sparsely populated voids to the formation sites of massive clusters.  This collaborative program addresses this problem by uniting researchers at Penn State, UT-Austin, and Texas A&M in an investigation of a 24 sq deg patch of sky that is being studied by six major surveys. The synergy of optical imaging from the Dark Energy Camera, near-IR imaging from NEWFIRM, mid-IR imaging from Spitzer-IRAC, far-IR imaging from Herschel-SPIRE, X-ray imaging from Chandra, combined with future optical spectroscopy from the Hobby Eberly Telescope Dark Energy  Experiment (HETDEX)  will transform our understanding of an epoch when the universe was only 2 to 4 billion years old.

children.name: TG-AST190001
children.project_abstract: Radiative transfer techniques in both cosmological simulations and for the purpose of making synthetic observations have recently become increasingly robust, leading to several predictions and new discoveries in a variety of fields.  Unfortunately, simulations run to the late Universe are forced to sacrifice physical and modeling detail due to computing limitations, which leaves the epoch fertile to observationally-constrained semi-analytic or empirical modeling efforts to bridge this gap. However, new phenomena and environments that lie on the edge of our observational frontier are less constrained and would benefit from a well-tested, first principles approach to numerical modeling. We propose to perform these tests by bringing full-physics ``zoom-in" cosmological simulations forward to the present day whereupon we will conduct a thorough Monte Carlo radiative transfer analysis on the resulting galaxies. After comparing and validating our techniques against observations, we will then proceed to produce detailed, high-resolution mock catalogs of both local galaxies and their higher-redshift progenitors. We will be able to provide predictions of light to mass ratios, half-light radii, emission line strengths, UV luminosity as well as other measures and correlate them directly to the composition, evolution history, and inclination of various types of galaxies. Our goal is to better account for micro physics in applications throughout galactic astronomy as well as facilitate tighter bounds and higher confidence for future novel observations.

children.name: TG-AST190005
children.project_abstract: Turbulence and magnetic reconnection are ubiquitous in astrophysical environments. In most situations, these processes do not occur in isolation, but interact with each other. This renders a comprehensive understanding of these processes highly challenging. Clarifying their properties is of paramount importance to understand the mechanisms for particle acceleration in various astrophysical systems where nonthermal emissions are observed. Here we study the mutual interplay between turbulence and magnetic reconnection by means of first-principle particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations of electron-ion plasmas in magnetically dominated systems (i.e., in the "relativistic" regime). With this Research Allocation Request, which follows a Startup Allocation in which we assessed the scalability of the used code (TRISTANÂ­-MP) on Stampede2, we want to perform large scale three-dimensional relativistic kinetic (both electrons and ions) simulations in order to investigate the effects of magnetic reconnection in the turbulent cascade and how this affects particle acceleration. These results will have important implications for the origin of nonthermal particles in high-energy astrophysical sources.

children.name: TG-AST040034N
children.project_abstract:
The observed masses and orbital periods for many classes of close binary systems are difficult to reproduce in evolutionary scenarios without significant mass and angular momentum loss.  A mechanism which facilitates these losses involves the transfer of orbital angular momentum to a common envelope which is subsequently ejected as a result of gravitational interactions.  This common envelope phase will be investigated in this proposal.  The effort will be focused 
on three dimensional hydrodynamical studies of the evolution of two cores within a common envelope.  We will perform evolutionary studies which will lead to formation of cataclysmic 
variable systems.  Specific parameters affecting the outcome of the evolution, that include the mass of each of the components of the system and their evolutionary state, will be investigated. 
We propose to carry out such calculations using the adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) simulation code FLASH.

children.name: TG-AST140080
children.project_abstract:
We request computing time and storage space on XSEDE resources, principally
  Stampede or Gordon, to run a zoom-in cosmological simulation of the formation
  of the Local Group of galaxies using a stellar feedback model that has already
  been shown to produce realistic galaxies at both the dwarf and Galaxy scales.
  We aim to constrain the gas kinematics, which will allow for better detections
  of the CGM, in addition to detailed studies of both field and satellite dwarf
  galaxies, such as the resultant density profiles and requirements for the
  quenching of star formation.  We will create the initial conditions with
  MUSIC, which self-consistently samples the matter power spectrum in the early
  Universe, evolve the simulation with the TreePM+SPH code Gizmo, a version of
  the mature code Gadget that models the physics relevant to galaxy formation, 
  identify collapsed structures with Rockstar, a six-dimensional halo finder, 
  track them through time with consistent-trees, an advanced merger-tree algorithm, and 
  perform the final analysis using tools developed within the collaboration.  We 
  have extensively tested all of these software packages, both on our own 
  computational resources and XSEDE computers, and are confident that our request 
  of 3.99M SUs is an accurate estimate of that required to reach the scientific goals.

children.name: TG-AST170038
children.project_abstract:
The numerical simulations proposed here utilize implementation of dark matter (DM) microphysics
of self-interaction. These physical eects on Local Group substructures has been discussed
in several previous astrophysical simulations [1, 2, 3]. However, those simulations are
usually done to focus on inner structure of dwarf galaxies, and not ideal for study the tidal
interaction between dwarf satellite galaxies and Milky Way (MW) potential. Our primary goals
and astrophysical applications include: (1) We will examine the tidal interaction of Galactic substructures in the self-interacting dark
matter (SIDM) scenario in a cosmological context. We will do so with a self-consistent
growth of MW potential including hierarchy formation through halo merger and galactic
disk potential modeling. (2) We will derive the MW satellite galaxy analog evolution properties such as their orbital
history, dynamical mass and compare with observational data. We will also perform comparison
between dierent DM model predictions, e.g. cold dark matter (CDM) and warm
dark matter (WDM). (3) We will determine the eciencies of tidal destruction and tidal debris formation when the
inner structure of substructure is altered by microphysics of SIDM. These high-resolution
simulations will be critical for understanding the evolution of some of these stellar tidal debris
that will be soon within the reach of future deep wide-eld imaging/spectroscopic surveys.

children.name: TG-AST120062
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TG-AST140064
children.project_abstract:
This is a request to continue our program of novel, high-resolution simulations of super-massive black hole (BH) growth and galaxy evolution, which will resolve the interstellar medium (ISM) and both fueling and feedback from BHs with fundamentally new physics on galactic scales. This will extend and improve on work over the last year using a previous XSEDE research allocation (Resolving Feedback from Super Massive Back Holes in a Realistic Interstellar Medium; PI Hopkins), particularly taking advantage of the numerical and physical advances that allocation enabled to generate a systematic suite of simulations studying feedback in different environments, which will be used to address a vast array of fundamental science questions.
In these simulations, the ISM will be explicitly resolved into diffuse and dense molecular cloud phases, with stars forming only in high-density bound cores, while both gravitational capture and accretion into the sub-pc scales of the viscous accretion disk by the BH will be explicitly resolved. When stars form, or mass is accreted onto the BH, energy and momentum is injected into the surrounding media via stellar and active galactic nucleus (AGN) feedback. We self-consistently incorporate the effects of radiation pressure (from stars and the AGN accretion disk), stellar and accretion disk winds, supernovae types I & II, and photo-ionization as well as Compton heating (by stars and AGN). This generates explosive galactic outflows and drives turbulence within both dense and diffuse gas in galaxies.
We will use these simulations to for the first time study accretion and feedback from AGN while simultaneously treating the ISM on galactic scales in a realistic fashion, without ad hoc prescriptions which have been used in previous numerical studies. In this investigation, our proposed simulations focus on a range of scales, from small-scale simulations of the obscuring torus region which can resolve inflow into scales of the viscous BH accretion disk, up through fully galaxy-scale simulations. This will allow us to simulate a range of different processes and develop an understanding of how small-scale physics of AGN accretion and driving of accretion-disk winds impacts galactic star formation and evolution at a much larger scale.
Because of their unique realism and range of physics incorporated, the proposed simulations will be used to address a wide range of current open scientific questions. We will study the evolution of BH accretion rates, generation of nuclear and galactic-scale winds, the interaction of AGN- driven and stellar-driven galactic outflows, the effects of AGN feedback on galactic star formation, and the nature of BH-host galaxy correlations. XSEDE resources are necessary to provide the computational power to perform these simulations, as the resolution demands exceed what can be achieved with local computing resources. We will use the new code GIZMO, that allows us to run simulations with either a moving-mesh method, or a novel formulation of smooth particle hydrodynamics (SPH). These simultaneously capture many of the advantages of Eulerian (grid) and Lagrangian codes, and allow us to directly isolate their discrepancies.
We have successfully performed test runs using the production version of the code on local computing clusters, and have run previous simulations using Stampede at TACC. This allows us to estimate runtime requirements for the proposed simulations, totaling 3.6 million SUs.

children.name: TG-MCA08X016
children.project_abstract: We propose a multi-year effort to continue our research into the magnetohydrodynamics of the solar interior.  We use -local- domain, high resolution simulations of the processes found in the solar interior to try and understand the production of the magnetic activity observed at the solar surface.  These processes are complex and operate in the highly turbulent regime, and therefore demand enormous computing power to simulate the dynamics at sufficient resolution and for sufficient time to garner meaningful statistics from the turbulence.  We have made significant progress with LRAC resources on this long-term project over the last 10 years or more, and request continuing support to continue this program.

children.name: TG-MCA07S014
children.project_abstract:
This proposal from the Laboratory for omputational Astrophysics, UCSD requests resources to continue our numerical studies of interstellar turbulence. Significant improvements and extensions of the Enzo adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) code for cosmology and astrophysics in the past year, as well as deployment of a new Sun Constellation 
Linux Cluster at TACC create new opportunities to increase the dynamic range of turbulence simulations. The main science focus of this year's proposal is shifting from  the last year's isothermal simulations of turbulence on scales of 10pc and below towards multiphase interstellar turbulence simulations in larger boxes with linear size up to 250pc. Our new problem setup will include the effects of distributed heating and radiative cooling, magnetic fields, and self-gravity. With AMR technique, we will be able to resolve all relevant physical scales better than in existing multiphase simulations. A set of numerical experiments with effective grid resolutions up to 4,096^3 (0.06pc) will allow us to: (i) address the problem of molecular cloud formation, (ii) study the statistics of multiphase turbulent flows, and (iii) compare different driving mechanisms for interstellar turbulence and
their imprints in turbulent statistics. The major goal of this project is to improve our understanding of scaling laws governing turbulent dynamics and to provide physical models for the observed structures in the molecular and atomic interstellar medium.

children.name: NCHRP-12-113
children.project_abstract: This project is focused on the loading and member stress ranges for the evaluate of the fatigue performance of bracing is steel bridges.  The program Abacus will be used to carry out parametric studies on the behavior of steel bridge systems.
children.pi_institution: Phil M Ferguson Structural Engineering Laboratory

children.name: TG-DMR140096
children.project_abstract: Organic photovoltaics (OPVs) comprise a promising class of solar cells with a number of unique and desirable qualities. These materials promise the ability to produce a flexible, inexpensive, and thin solar cell as a structurally more versatile and economically more attractive alternative to silicon-based solar cells.  The efficiency of the relatively new OPV materials has not yet reached that of conventional silicon based solar cells and needs to be increased before wide scale commercial application can be realized. OPVs are efficient absorbers of light, but depend upon exciton diffusion, dissociation, and eventually electron-hole separation to generate photocurrent. Competing against these processes is the complementary set of exciton trapping, recombination, and radiative or non-radiative decay. Maximizing the former set and minimizing or negating the latter are available routes to improve efficiency and allow for OPVs to become a viable renewable energy source. Perhaps the most critical complicating factor in understanding OPVs is that the performance is highly sensitive to molecular order, and large variance in molecular order can be seen even within the same polymer, depending on processing protocol.  The research for which this proposal requests support is focused on understanding these performance factors on a fundamental and molecular level in order to aid in the understanding and design of OPV device performance.

children.name: TG-CTS090025
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: TurbulenceDNS
children.project_abstract:
Due to instrumentation limitations, it is widely agreed that for
simple turbulent flows at modest Reynolds number, the most reliable
source of detailed data is the direct numerical simulation (DNS) of
the flow. As is well known, in DNS the governing equations for fluid
flow (the Navier-Stokes equations) are solved numerically for
three-dimension time-dependent solutions with sufficient spatial and
temporal resolution to accurately represent all the scales of
turbulence. In this project, we propose to conduct DNS for two
important flow situations to provide specific information as indicated
below:

1) Simulations of homogeneous isotropic incompressible flows will be
   conducted at several Reynolds numbers to determine how the maximum
   Lyapunov exponent scales with Reynolds number, domain size, and
   other relevant parameters. This is important for determining
   predictability of the details of the turbulence, and for defining
   time horizons over which standard adjoint sensitivity analysis can
   be conducted.

2) Simulations of idealized compressible high energy turbulent
   boundary layers will be conducted to obtain reliable statistical
   information to be used in the calibration and model selection of
   RANS turbulence models.

children.name: TG-DMR100005
children.project_abstract:
Recent successful fabrication of graphene and few-layer graphene in experiment has ignited tremendous research interest. The unique electronic structure of graphene gives rise to many outstanding features and broad potential applications. However, the lack of a finite band gap is a big obstacle for the application of graphene on practical microelectronic devices because the intrinsic-graphene-based transistor cannot be switched off by the controlling voltage. Therefore, how to generate a finite band gap and, moreover, how to control the band gap are urgent and important research tasks.

Experimental and theoretical studies have shown a few approaches to modify the electronic structure and band gap of graphene and bilayer graphene. We will focus on two of them; one is the chemical adsorption of molecules onto the graphene sheet; the other one is applying electric field to induce a finite band gap in bilayer graphene. For the first research topic, we plan to carry out first-principles studies to reveal how the molecules are adsorbed by graphene at the quantum-mechanics level and discover what kind of patterns these molecules prefer to form. For the second research topic, we will perform the first-principles calculation to study how the applied electric field induces a finite band gap in bilayer graphene. Many-electron effects will be included for the first time. Through this study we expect to explain the discrepancy between the prior theoretical calculations and experimental measurements and explore how important many-electron effects are in the electronic structure of two-dimensional semimetals. Finally, the change of the electronic structure induced by above methods will definitely have impact on the optical response of graphene and bilayer graphene. We plan to study optical absorption spectra of bilayer graphene under an applied electric field with many-electron effects included. Through this study, we hope to understand how electron-hole interactions modify the infrared optical absorption spectra of bilayer graphene with a finite band gap.

In order to realize above research plans, a powerful and efficient parallelized computing platform is of importance. Therefore, we write this proposal to TeraGrid for necessary computing allocation. We believe that these proposed plans will not only improve our understanding of the electronic structure and optical response of graphene but also significantly contribute to practical applications of this novel material. Moreover, our research plans will benefit the computational condensed matter research community in Washington University and St. Louis region and provide excellent opportunities for researchers to learn attractive properties of graphene and many-electron effects on nanostructures.

children.name: QUANTRANS
children.project_abstract: Understanding electronic and thermal transport in nanomaterials and at nanoscale interfaces inherently requires a hierarchical, multi-dimensional approach that is able to bridge the atomistic description of the complexity of nanosystems with the continuum models based on thermodynamics and the Boltzmann equation. The objective of our research is to theoretically investigate and develop appropriate models for electron/spin and phonon/thermal transport in nanoscale structures within a complex environment, by developing a hierarchical approach that can bridge the quantum mechanical aspects of transport properties at the atomistic level with the understanding and ultimately the prediction of how these phenomena depend on the local environment around the nanostructure, which in turn depends on macroscale processing conditions. Clearly, hierarchical methods that span quantum mechanics at the atomic scale up to macroscopic scale continuum models across disparate length and time scales are crucial for developing accurate and validated guidelines that can be used to design new materials and interfaces with revolutionary functionalities for efficient current and heat management. At the same time, we will develop a working understanding of interface structure and dynamics in nanostructured interfaces in order to define the descriptors of the dominant physical behaviors. This includes the accurate determination of interface geometry (including defects, strains, misfits and dislocations), its electronic structure and vibrational properties and performance under operating temperatures and voltages.

children.name: TG-DMR190076
children.project_abstract:
Fundamental studies into the structural and electronic properties of strongly-correlated materials, including d- and f- electrons systems, which
gives rise to a rich variety of phenomena, and this remains a serious test for electronic-structure theories.  In this effort, we will conduct detailed investigations into some typical d- and f- electrons systems, where we will attempt to answer some of the most pressing questions about why traditional DFT may be failed in these filed and SCAN can capture the electronic structures of strongly correlated materials.

Computational design of cheap catalysts by intercalations of earth-abundant atoms and defect engineering of layered materials. We will test the versatile vdW functional SCAN+rVV10 on molecular adsorptions on metal surfaces and extract the C3 coefficients. We will also use SCAN+rVV10 to study the mechanism of the CO2 reduction by MXenes with and without defects, which have the potential to generate cheap, easily synthesized, and precious metal-free catalysts for CO2 conversion to hydrocarbon-based fuels.

children.name: TG-DMR130081
children.project_abstract:
Layered, two-dimensional materials offer a wide range of physical properties.  They include topological insulators, Dirac Fermions, metals, semimetals, semiconductors, and charge density waves.  Layers can be registered to each other or be randomly misoriented.  Random orientation can electronically decouple the layers even though they are only a few angstroms apart.  Electronic structure calculations coupled with a study of the vibrational properties of materials is required to understand the electronic, thermal, and thermoelectric properties.  One interesting subclass of materials are transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD), which exhibit semiconducting, semi-metallic and metallic conducting properties.  TMD compounds consist of covalently bonded trilayers (TL) that are held together by weak vdW forces along the c-axis.  Ab-initio calculations of the electron and the phonon properties can be used to understand a range of phenomena exhibited by this class of materials which includes novel electronic, thermal, thermoelectric, and charge-density-wave properties.  

This research is funded by the NSF-1124733 (NSF-NRI NEB 2020) and MARCO/SRC/DARPA through the center on Functional Accelerated nanoMaterial Engineering (FAME).

children.name: A-ph91
children.project_abstract: We are interested in first principles calculations of graphene sheets, bilayers, and graphene-based materials.  Graphene possesses unique electronic properties that bring up fundamental questions in condensed matter theory, and is currently one of the most studied systems (as well as having potential applications).  Our group is among the world leaders in research in the field, but as deeper questions are addressed we shall need larger computational power. We are grateful that we can use the resources provided by TACC.

children.name: Performing-Ultra-Low
children.project_abstract:
Several key challenges present themselves to realize energy-efficient detection, localization and isotope identification. We will focus on drastically reducing the power consumption for the matrix-vector multiplications that lie at the heart of least-squares or modified least-squares methods of the algorithmic detection of isotopes in spectra.
Present-day computational approaches are increasingly limited by the power consumption associated with memory and transferring data between different memories. We propose to develop topological-insulator random-access memory (TIRAM) that is non-volatile, energy-efficient, high-density, and does not require dedicated read-out circuitry. To realize such a device, we start from the exciting recent discovery of large-gap two-dimensional topological insulators (2D TIs). We will study 2D TIs coupled with 2D ferromagnets to exploit the ability of 2D TIs to inject electrons with a desired spin with 100% efficiency into ferromagnetic storage layers. We will study TIRAM intrinsic performance, the robustness against imperfections offered by topological protection, and the efficiency of performing matrix-vector multiplications using TIRAMs.
In a second stage of the research, we will investigate the combination of the newly developed memory with TI-based field-effect transistors (TIFETs) which have recently been shown to exhibit lower power consumption and higher performance than any alternative emerging computing device. The co-integration of TIRAMs with TIFETs will yield immediate significant power savings and can eventually lead to non-von Neumann brain-inspired artificial neural networks that can perform pattern recognition tasks orders of magnitudes more efficiently compared to any conventional approach.

children.name: TG-DMR190070
children.project_abstract: In this proposal we request a computational allocation to the TACC Stampede 2 supercomputer, in support of our research on the development of predictive excited-state calculations for extended solids. This research allocation will support an ongoing binational project, that has been awarded a three year NSF grant in 2017. The purpose of this broader project is to develop a reliable workflow for the calculation of excited state properties of semiconductors and insulators, using many body perturbation theory and range separated hybrid functionals (RSH). This project has evolved to include three main thrust areas: (1) access the ability of RSH to capture many-body effects relative to higher levels of theory, (2) devise an first principles material-specific framework for determining all parameters appearing in the RSH functional, and (3) use RSH as a starting point for more sophisticated many body calculations within the GW-BSE approach.  This proposal is concerned primarily with the third thrust area and structured as follows. In the main document we will give an outline of the scientific background of our research, followed by a detailed description of the methodology we employ, the milestones earmarked for this specific allocation, the research plan devised to achieve these milestones, as well as a point-by-point breakdown of the requested resources. Furthermore, we attach four auxiliary documents that include the list of references cited in this proposal, a separate discussion on the performance of the software we plan to use and the CVs of the PI (Jeffrey Neaton) and the co-PI (Marina Filip).

children.name: BORN-PT-Unconvention
children.project_abstract:
Alongside alternative clean energy sources, energy recovery and conversion will play an important role in addressing future technologies, especially for autonomous devices. Thermoelectric (TE) devices that convert temperature gradients into electric power and vice versa have been actively investigated with the aim of enhancing existing technologies for heat/power recovery and conversion. They are reliable, non-polluting, require minimal maintenance, and can be operated over a wide range of temperatures.
This project aims at significantly increasing zT values of thermoelectrics by nanostructuring TE materials into NC solids that can offer high electrical conductivity while dramatically lowering the thermal conductivity. We propose an approach for creating completely new high-zT thermoelectrics via bottom-up assembly of TE NCs into binary nanocrystal superlattices (BNSLs). 
 We will use ab initio modeling for predicting electrical and thermal transport in the NC superlattices, and corroborate the obtained results with the experimental data. The predictive power of dynamic models will also be used to guide the self-assembly efforts.

children.name: battery
children.project_abstract:
The design of novel materials is critical for many potential new
and clean energy technologies. Whether it is hydrogen or solar, thermoelectrics
or energy storage, the effectiveness of these technologies is severely limited
by the available materials. Focused on energy storage in current Li-ion batteries,
the use of a cobalt oxide as the most common material in the cathode is approaching
to its end, due to the fact that the Co must be obtained from natural resources.
So, while the new generation of Li-air batteries are still been developed in the
labs, we must concentrate our efforts in the search of new materials to be used as cathode
in Li-ion batteries, to improve their efficiency and performance.
In this project, we are going to use first-principles calculations to compute
several properties (geometry, band gap, ionic conductivity,...) of some materials
we believe they are most likely suitable candidates for that purpose.

children.name: Quantitative-Macroec
children.project_abstract: In this project, I will work on several macroeconomic models that feature frictions in information acquisition. That is, unlike standard models, agents in the models in this project have a coarser information set. They make decisions rationally, but are not fully attentive and are able to process only a limited set of information. In this realistic real world setting, the projects will explore mostly the effects of policy changes on macroeconomic prices and quantities and asset prices. One project will look at closed economy models while the other will look at open economy models. Because of information frictions, solving these models is computationally very burdensome and resources available through Stampede 2 will be very useful for the research.

children.name: scRNA-seq
children.project_abstract: single cell RNA-seq testing

children.name: TG-MCB140147
children.project_abstract:
We have developed and continue to support the Galaxy genomic analysis system. Our main public Galaxy analysis website currently supports more than 50,000 genomics researchers performing hundreds of thousands of analysis jobs every month. Many academic and commercial institutions around the world operate private Galaxy instances.

Galaxy enables biomedical researchers to perform complex compute-intensive analyses with nothing to install and configure. It also allows tool developers to deploy their analysis applications without the need to design interfaces and maintain compute infrastructure. Both of these are profoundly felt. Despite the fact we do not put any requirements on citing our work, over 500 papers published in 2013 alone have utilized Galaxy as the analysis platform.

As a direct consequence of our initial success we have reached a point where we can no longer sustain the exponential growth of analysis load and associated biological data storage on our public servers. In order to extend our capacity we are requesting XSEDE Gateway allocation aimed at establishing a national computational biology gateway.

children.name: TG-MCB190047
children.project_abstract: Atomistic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are frequently used to evaluate the structure of intermediate (1-100 kDa) proteins, especially those exhibiting well-defined globular morphologies. However, validation of protein structures is often limited to global comparisons to static experimental structures, despite fluctuations in solution NMR that indicate that solvent-exposed amino acids interconvert between states in a thermodynamic ensemble. While it is well known that amino acids in globular cores remain tightly packed together, we recently identified a fixed percolation geometry in these regions that also persists in the presence of small mutations or thermal fluctuations. This key observation enables us to implement a novel technique that quickly validates physiological and pathological protein structures from MD, in addition to predicting putative structures based on the conservation of core residue percolation. Compared to traditional enhanced-sampling methods, where protein conformations are extracted from the most probable states, the use of side-chain percolation allows decoy states to be filtered out and discarded. As a result, simulations can focus on states that are thermodynamically consistent with known experimental ensembles, rather than on a singular protein fold. In order to develop this technique into a widely-utilized tool for efficient protein folding, we propose the following two projects: (1) to measure how often proteins implicated in physiological and pathological processes interconvert between known conformations as a result of MD fluctuations, and whether such fluctuations vary across popular force fields. (2) to identify how conformational mutations affect the interconversion between physiological and pathological states while conserving globular percolation, especially in the context of cancer and Alzheimerâ??s Disease. Taken as a whole, the ability to filter true protein structures from energy-minimized decoys will greatly reduce the need for very long protein folding simulations and can inform how proteins pathological misfold within their thermodynamic limitations.

children.name: Circadian-genomics
children.project_abstract: The long-term goals of the Takahashi laboratory are to understand the molecular and genetic basis of circadian rhythms in mammals and to utilize forward genetic approaches in the mouse as a tool for gene discovery for complex behavior. We have focused our attention in three areas: 1) identification of circadian clock genes and assignment of their function in the molecular mechanism of the circadian pacemaker; 2) analysis of central and peripheral circadian oscillators using real-time circadian reporters; and 3) identification of genes defined by mutations isolated in the large-scale mutagenesis screens we have conducted on neural and behavioral phenotypes including psychostimulant responses and contextual and cue dependent fear conditioning. Recently, we have focused on the structural biology of circadian clock proteins and on genome-wide analysis of transcription factor binding and gene expression using next generation sequencing methods. A comprehensive global analysis of circadian transcription factor binding in the mouse liver has been completed in which all core components of the clock gene pathway have been interrogated. In addition, we have also analyzed the genome-wide regulation of nascent transcription, RNA polymerase II occupancy and epigenomic regulation of chromatin by the circadian clock.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

children.name: TG-MCA05S027
children.project_abstract: Alzheimer's disease, one of the leading causes of dementia, is caused by the pathological self-assembly of the 40 to 42-long Alzheimer Amyloid-beta(Ab) peptide into aggregate species. Aggregation is believed to be nucleated at a turn region located in the 21-30 segment of this peptide and mutations of residues E22 and D23 have been shown to affect the ability of these peptides to aggregate. We propose to perform replica exchange molecular dynamics simulations on E22 and D23 mutants of the 21-30 fragment of the (Ab) peptide to investigate how these substitutions affect the folding mechanisms and conformations of these peptides and in turn their aggregation propensities.

children.name: TG-MCB080116N
children.project_abstract:
This project will focus on the energetics of the sequence of
  electronic transitions in bacteria resulting in the separation of
  charge across the membrane caused by the absorption of a photon of
  visible light. We will run classical MD trajectories of the
  bacterial reaction center in order to extract two types of
  information: dynamics of the fluctuations of the donor-acceptor
  energy gap for the electronic hops and the equilibrium distributions
  of energy gaps. The latter will provide us with the free energy
  surfaces of electronic hopping transitions directly used in the
  calculation of the reaction rates.  The main question we address in
  this study is the details of the mechanism by which natural systems
  eliminate wasteful recombination rates allowing quantum efficiency
  exceeding 99&. This information will be used to formulate practical
  suggestions for photosynthetic conversion of light energy applicable
  to artificial photosynthesis.

children.name: CMPS-5433-MWSU
children.project_abstract: According to the Department of Energy (DOE), and the White House, the potential benefits and skills associated with High Performance Computing (HPC) not only extend well beyond computer science but also into the upcoming decades in support of any computational science. HPC and Big-Data will play a key role in the scientific, technological and economic leadership of the USA. For these and many other reasons, on July 29, 2015 the Obama administration signed an executive order in which the following goals are highlighted: the maximization of HPC research, development, deployment and workforce development. In this class we will explore important concepts such as: Speedup, Amdahl's law, Race Condition, and concurrency, among many others. It is also our goal to train members of the future HPC workforce in multicore and many-core environments, and show them how to harness the potential of these architectures through the use of MPI, OPENMP and CUDA.

children.name: TG-ATM160026
children.project_abstract:
Accurate prediction of convective hazardous weather is critical from both meteorological and public service/societal impact perspectives, but remains a major challenge. The uncertainties in numerical weather prediction (NWP) models as well as the high nonlinearity of convective weather make probabilistic forecast information that can be provided by convection-allowing ensembles especially valuable to forecasters. Advanced data assimilation (DA) is needed to provide accurate initial conditions (IC) while optimized ensemble-based DA techniques such as the ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) can provide theoretically the best possible estimate of the initial condition uncertainties what are needed to initialize ensemble forecasting systems.  
CAPS has since 2007 continued to push the envelope of high-performance computing, conducting highly successful realtime storm-scale ensemble forecast (SSEF) experiments utilizing XSEDE computing resources at PSC, NICS and TACC, in collaboration with the NOAA Hazardous Weather Testbed (HWT) Spring Forecasting Experiment (SFE), and since 2016 the NOAA Hydrometeorological Testbed (HMT) Flash Flood and Intensive Rainfall (FFaIR) Experiment. CAPS realtime experiments are designed to test and evaluate the most advanced data assimilation systems and ensemble forecasting techniques designed for predicting high-resolution convective-scale weather, and the data sets generated will be used by the CAPS scientists as well as collaborators to help answer many scientific questions related to the prediction of severe weather. Close collaborating organizations include the NOAA National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) operational centers (The Storm Prediction Center, Weather Prediction Center, and Environmental Modeling Center), research centers include the National Center for Atmospheric Research and the Developmental Testbed Center). The experiments are expected to lead to optimal designs and advanced capabilities that can be implemented at the NCEP Operational Centers, and thereby to improve forecasting of severe weather such as tornadoes, severe hail, damaging winds, and flash floods.  The CAPS forecast data sets generated on the TerGrid and Xsede resources have resulted in more than 40 referred journal publications. 
Through this proposal, scientists from CAPS seeks XSEDE resources on TACC Stampede and PSC Bridges to support its 2017 realtime storm-scale ensemble data assimilation and forecasting and related research in collaboration with the 2017 HWT SFE and HMT FFaIR forecast experiments. Such research has large-scale computing requirements that can only be satisfied by XSEDE. New scientific questions will be addressed by the experiments.

children.name: TG-ATM140042
children.project_abstract: n/a

children.name: -Plane-wave-Electron
children.project_abstract:
https://nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1710066

A great variety of consumer electronics, such as laptops and smartphones, rely on tiny nanometer-size electronic switches. To further improve and develop new electronic switches that can be manufactured more cheaply and consume less power, new device concepts based on novel two-dimensional materials rather than conventional silicon technologies have been proposed and new research is needed to assess their potential properties. An important step in the development of such new electronic switches is computer simulations incorporating the physical elements that control the charge transport. Many important breakthroughs have been realized in electronic transport simulations and quantum transport is routinely simulated using a host of tools available to the community. However, all of these currently available tools start from the chemist's "tight-binding" viewpoint rather than from the physicist's "plane-wave" vantage point. Unfortunately, certain physical processes that are important in two-dimensional materials are difficult to be treated correctly using the tight-binding basis. The goal of this project is to transform the way quantum transport is studied by moving from the tight-binding basis to the plane-wave basis. This project will develop a plane-wave based quantum transport code capable of studying novel electronic devices. The project will also include a study of conventionally-scaled electronic devices as well as newly proposed devices and materials that present important routes toward the realization of a more energy-efficient electronics. This project will also generate a pipeline of students motivated to study science and engineering at universities through participation in various outreach programs at the University of Texas at Dallas. 

Specifically, the project will develop a plane-wave based code capable of studying quantum transport in nanoscale devices such as nanowires and nanoribbons. Efficient plane-wave algorithms to reduce computational memory and time requirements and a robust capability of studying the effects of spin-orbit coupling will be implemented in the code. Electronic dissipative scattering in these nanoscale devices will be dealt with using the Pauli Master equation. Important physical phenomena that will be incorporated are: scattering with phonons, defects, and edge roughness. Of particular interest is scattering with the flexural out-of-plane phonons which are hard to describe in a localized basis set. The atomic-scale dielectric response in these low-dimensional systems will also be studied. Using the developed quantum transport code, a wide variety of devices, such as conventional field-effect transistors, tunneling-based field-effect transistors, and topological-insulator field-effect transistors, will be studied. The research will elucidate the impact of flexural out-of-plane phonon modes on the electronic-transport characteristics of low-dimensional materials. The effects of spin-orbit coupling on transport will be determined. How the interplay between spin-orbit coupling and the electron-phonon interaction affects transport will be clarified. Finally, the research will also unravel the important physical processes in future field-effect transistors and determine how to deal with possible detrimental effects such as line-edge roughness.

children.name: TG-PHY180013
children.project_abstract: The vast majority of observed planets and stars possess self-generated, large-scale magnetic fields. These magnetic fields are sustained through the motion of electrically conducting fluids within their interiors via the so-called dynamo mechanism, which converts the kinetic energy of fluid motion into electromagnetic energy. Understanding the physics of these systems remains a challenging task due to the extreme physical parameters that characterize these systems. For instance, natural dynamos are typically dominated by two or more forces; the remaining forces are relatively small and play a very subtle role that remains poorly understood. Moreover, rotation and magnetic fields introduce inhomogeneity and anisotropy into the flow field and a general understanding of their influence on the statistics of turbulence is lacking. This proposal seeks to overcome this limitation by performing one of the most detailed investigations to date of convection-driven magnetohydrodynamic turbulence, with a particular focus on understanding how magnetic waves influence the dynamics. We will use a combination of state-of-the-art asymptotic models and high resolution direct numerical simulation of the complete set of governing equations.

children.name: TG-PHY190017
children.project_abstract:
Particle physics and string models often 
		 predict the existence of topological defects such as magnetic 
		 monopoles and cosmic strings. Magnetic monopoles are like 
		 isolated North (or South) poles of a bar magnet; cosmic 
		 strings are tubes of energy. These would exist in a
