		 cosmological setting and their discovery would have important 
		 ramifications for our understanding of fundamental physics.  
		 Topological defects could also have helped shape the current 
		 universe. Magnetic monopole-antimonopole pairs may have played 
		 a role in the generation of the observed matter-antimatter 
		 asymmetry in the universe. Cosmic strings emit high energy 
		 particles that can be observed as cosmic rays. They also emit 
		 gravitational radiation that ongoing experiments are 
		 searching. Topological defects are soliton-like solutions of 
		 Yang-Mills-Higgs (YMH) equations that exist for topological 
		 reasons. Such solutions have been constructed and studied for 
		 several decades now. However, less work has been done on 
		 dynamical questions â??Ã?Ã¬ how do monopole and antimonopole 
		 scatter? what is the dynamics of monopole-antimonopole bound 
		 states? what is the dynamics of cosmic string loops and how 
		 much particle radiation do they emit? There is urgency to 
		 answer these questions as gravitational wave detectors (e.g.  
		 LIGO)  have to compare their observations with those of 
		 theoretical predictions. The only way to address such 
		 questions is to numerically evolve the YMH equations of 
		 motion, together with weak field gravity equations to evaluate  
		 gravitational radiation. Our code, "goYMH", has been 
		 successfully used in serial and parallel on the Agave cluster 
		 at Arizona State University for small scale problems, 
		 resulting in multiple publications. To advance our main goals 
		 further, we will be requesting a full research allocation 
		 through XSEDE and would, therefore, like to benchmark our 
		 code's performance on the Stampede 2 system.

children.name: TG-PHY180030
children.project_abstract: We request 0.352 million SUs computing allocation on Stampede2 (SKX compute nodes), 2.688 million SUs compute allocation on Comet (standard compute nodes), 46,500 GBs storage allocation on Ranch and 12,500 GBs storage allocation on SDSC Data Oasis. This proposal is based on two main projects that have been previously approved and funded by NSF: Project A. Quantum Materials from geometric and dimensionality design, reviewed and accepted by NSF-DMR, project date June 15, 2018 â?? May 31, 2021, award number: 1724791; Project B. Predictive theory, synthesis and characterization of a new type of transparent conductor without doping, reviewed and accepted by NSF-DMR, project date July 1, 2018 â?? June 30, 2021, award number: 1806939. In project A, we propose to build upon our recent successful preliminary work on geometric and dimensionality design to obtain Quantum Materials with emergent properties that greatly supersede or are even qualitatively absent from those attainable from the individual compound building blocks. The main â??knobsâ?? involve a search for specific superstructure patterns (A)n/(B)m/(A)p/(B)nâ??/â?¦ (where n, m, p, nâ??... are the repeat periods of the building blocks compounds A, B), or polymorphs with specifically reduced symmetries that deliver unusual, emergent quantum properties. In project B, we realize that the current method of choice for discovering new transparent conductors have relied on heavily doping transparent insulators until they become conducting, while unfortunately, wide gap materials are intrinsically resistant to doping of charges because of the existence of â??doping bottlenecksâ??, thus consequently, the progress in finding and optimizing such technologically critical transparent conducting oxide materials has been frustratingly slow. We propose an opposite, and likely more fruitful alternative of designing transparency in metals by looking for compounds that obey a set of â??design principlesâ? with specific band structures. The design rules for our proposed intrinsic transparent conductors are: (i) identify a compound with metallic band structure; such that (ii) it has low plasma frequency and (iii) low inter-band optical absorption across the Fermi level, and (iv) apply synthesis and characterization to the â??best of classâ? compounds. The most visible advantage of metallic transparent conductors is that their conductivity comes from their high, indigenous carrier concentration. Such rare compounds could not have been identified by chance, and currently require a trial-and-error Edisonian method.

children.name: Electron-properties
children.project_abstract: In this project, we want to calculate the electron properties of some two-dimensional systems by applying semi-classical theory.

children.name: TG-PHY110016
children.project_abstract:
Magnetised turbulence plays a significant role in a variety of astrophysical and laboratory processes, ranging from the generation of large-scale magnetic fields in stellar interiors, to the transport of angular momentum in accretion discs and heating in the solar corona. Unfortunately, despite its wide-ranging applicability, magnetised turbulence has evaded a general physical understanding for many decades. The development of a firm theoretical foundation for magnetised turbulence remains one of the most important outstanding problems in astrophysics.

The development of the theory for magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence heavily relies on massively parallel numerical computations. The enormous increase in computational power over recent years has enabled high-resolution numerical simulations that have led to the discovery of an array of important new effects and a number of thought-provoking theoretical conjectures have been put forward. In particular, in the case of strong field-guided incompressible MHD turbulence it has been found that the turbulent domain spontaneously fragments into regions in which the velocity and magnetic fields are aligned within a small scale-dependent angle. The aligned structures have a number of important consequences, particularly on the efficiency of the energy cascade. Moreover, it has recently become apparent that our ability to measure the scale-dependence of the alignment angle, even at low Reynolds number where traditionally only a very short inertial range is detectable (thus making the identification of scaling laws difficult), may have uncovered a new result that could be related to a well-known phenomenon in isotropic hydrodynamic turbulence. The phenomenon is known as extended self-similarity, which refers to the empirical result that the universal region of self-similarity can be significantly extended if one plots a structure function versus a second structure function for which an exact expression is known, rather than naively plotting the structure function versus the increment. If this result can be extended to the anisotropic case of magnetised turbulence its implications will be widespread, as it will enable scaling laws to be determined from a statistical analysis of numerical or observational data sets of a much reduced resolution than would otherwise be necessary.

The aim is to investigate the phenomenon of extended self-similarity in the inertial range dynamics of strong incompressible MHD turbulence. We propose a series of high-resolution numerical simulations that will elucidate the character of this mechanism. The simulations will provide crucial information for developing a comprehensive phenomenological model of strong MHD
turbulence and will provide a useful tool for inferring the scaling properties of MHD turbulence from astrophysical observations.

children.name: TG-MCA07S017
children.project_abstract: We request an allocation of 4.0 million service units on the Cray XT3 "bigben", 2.0 million service units on the BlueGene/L at the San Diego Supercomputer Center, and 6.0 million service units on the TACC "ranger" to continue generating lattice QCD gauge-field configurations for a broad program of study in high-energy and nuclear physics, and for evaluating the correlation matrices of hadron operators using these configurations. Our goal is to compute the low-lying baryon and meson resonance spectrum using newly developed group-theory methods at pion masses down to 200 MeV using ab initio Markov-chain Monte Carlo integrations on anisotropic space-time lattices.  The majority of the excited states to be studied have never before been investigated in lattice QCD.  These calculations are important to many experimental efforts, but especially to those at Jefferson Laboratory.  Exotic hybrid mesons, a new form of excited matter, will be studied, and the photocouplings between some of these meson resonances will be determined.  The configurations generated will be useful for many other applications, as well, such as for determinations of nucleon-nucleon and nucleon-hyperon scattering lengths.

children.name: TG-IBN180001
children.project_abstract:
Despite of urgent needs, for many neurodegenerative disorders, no reliable, sensitive, non-invasive brain imaging markers with clinical utility have yet to exist. With an advent of rigorous computational data analytics, recent brain imaging studies have begun to show promising results. For example, multi-modal brain imaging provides complex pictures of abnormal brain structure and function that may underlie pathophysiology such as Alz-heimerâ??s disease or related dementia. There exists a urgent, unmet need in the field of clinical brain imaging for rigorous, data-driven, unbiased, computational approach to imag-ing-based biomarkers. Current dependence on parametric null hypothesis testing (e.g., t-test, ANOVA) hampers the development of computational brain imaging.
An overarching goal of our study is to determine novel brain imaging markers for Alz-heimerâ??s diseaseâ??using a complete data-driven machine learning approach. We will ulti-mately build a largest brain imaging database for rigorous deep and wide machine learn-ing based on tens of thousands of healthy and clinical samples. Towards this goal, in this research grant, we aim to analyze large brain imaging datasets. The first dataset includes multi-modal brain imaging from clinical cohorts (n=5,000) collected at a dementia clinic. The second dataset includes multimodal brain imaging from community-ascertained co-horts (n=20,000).
Using these datasets, in the first phase of the research, we will conduct computational im-aging analysis using well established, state-of-the-art imaging analysis pipelines, the core expertise of this research team (Cha, PI). This involves estimation of individual structural connectome. Then, in the second phase of the research, we will build deep neural net-work using the connectomic data to classify Alzheimerâ??s disease related dementia. Im-portantly, inspired by a novel transfer learning algorithm, the deep neural network will be pre-trained on a non-clinical population-based data; the pretrained model will be then ap-plied to the clinical cohort data. This goal is based on the core expertise of this research team (Yoo, co-PI). 
In a prior pilot data analysis, we have shown feasibility of our analytic plan. We have suc-cessfully test-run our analysis codes for brain volumetric and connectomic analysis in a subset (n=100) of the data using the allocation via the Campus Champion program. We are now ready to run the batch analysis over 10,000 individualsâ?? data.
This research will generate unprecedented brain imaging-derived phenotypes, such as structural connectomes and brain regional morphometry from 10,000 individuals. Also, neural network models trained on these data can be applied to many classification prob-lems existing in clinical neuroimaging and cognitive neuroscience. Upon receipt of exter-nal fundings, we plan to make all the data, models, and computer programs developed in this research program publicly accessible.

children.name: TG-CTS150062
children.project_abstract: The XSEDE request seeks computer resource allocation for a funded project on improved cooling technologies in the power generation sector. The award entitled Thermally Effective and Efficient Cooling Technologies for Advanced Gas Turbines  explores advanced strategies for external airfoil cooling. In this project a thermally effective counter cooling technique for land based power generation turbines is being investigated. In order to use full thermal capacity of the coolant fluid used for cooling purposes, a combined approach of internal and external cooling is used. This project focuses on the external cooling side where the coolant is discharged through a slot over the surface. For accurate computations, the spatial and temporal scales have to be resolved, and Large Eddy Simulations have to be performed. This intrinsically   involves large scale computations requiring parallel computing resources. An open source code called OpenFoam will be utilized for this purpose. The simulations would enable understanding of the detailed flow physics and heat transfer for this cooling configuration.

children.name: laminar-interactions
children.project_abstract: Shock/boundary-layer interactions are some of the most intractable problems in fluid mechanics and are also of critical importance in high-speed flight.  The advent of high-performance computing has allowed detailed investigations of such phenomena.  While interactions of practical importance are turbulent, we propose laminar interactions that capture essential physics without the complications and uncertainties involved with turbulence modeling.  The configuration of interest is a pair of swept shocks of opposite family crossing a boundary layer.  Depending on the strength of the shocks, a variety of complex interaction phenomena ensue.  Of particular interest is the possibility of symmetry breaking and its large unsteadiness as been observed experimentally in turbulent interactions.

children.name: Kinetics-of-selectiv
children.project_abstract: Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations of reaction mechanisms for currently experimentally developed reactions of catalytic carbon-heteroatom bond formation will be carried out using Gaussian software. The calculations will examine thermodynamic and kinetic properties of the reactions, including activation barriers for the key catalytic steps that lead to the formation of the carbon-heteroatom bonds. Both ground and excited state transformations will be examined by DFT calculations with the goal of understanding factors that govern the selectivity of reactions. Mechanisms of carbon-sulfur, carbon-phosphorus and carbon-nitrogen bond-forming reactions will be investigated to guide the development of new synthetic transformations for efficient and environmentally benign organic synthesis.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

children.name: ParallelBNP
children.project_abstract: In this project, we aim to develop accurate, distributed inference algorithms for Bayesian nonparametric models, including Dirichlet processes, Pitman-Yor processes, nested and hierarchical nonparametric models, and nonparametric hidden Markov models. We aim to explicitly incorporate parallelization into the models' structure, yielding results that are inherently parallelizable. The goal is to decrease the time required per iteration of the MCMC sampler, without degrading the estimate quality or increasing the number of iterations required for convergence.

children.name: Machine-learning-app
children.project_abstract: The purpose of this work is to assess the use of machine learning approaches to analyze brain imaging data for diagnostic and treatment response purposes. Previous work has identified a complex neural system associated with attention bias and that attention bias has been tied to vulnerability and maintenance of mental illness. We are fortunate to have access to a large database of multimodal neuroimaging data in well characterized individuals. Examining these datasets using machine and deep learning approaches promises to reveal key neural networks that support and predict negative attention bias as well as eventual response to treatment.

children.name: Automatic-Assessment
children.project_abstract: We investigate data intensive (VQC) video quality control algorithms to derive levels of distortions in massive video collections.

children.name: TG-CDA100010
children.project_abstract:
This proposal describes work on the multiscale simulation of complex realistic electrochemical systems where important physical phenomena span a wide range of length- and time-scales. The goals of the multi-year project have been to develop improved algorithms for multiscale simulation, to test their performance while quantifying uncertainty in physicochemical mechanisms and associated parameter values, and to utilize the simulations to design improved systems. To accomplish this goal, we have examined experimental data with sensitivity analysis, parameter estimation, and model selection tools. The initial physical application chosen for study was the copper electrodeposition processes for fabricating on-chip wiring interconnections between transistors, especially the role of trace amounts of additives that are critically important. In this proposal, new PIs are added that expand the range of numerical simulation methods as well as the physical applications.  The requested computational resources are for 1,966,860 SUs on the NCSA Xeon Linux Cluster (Abe/QueenBee). Support for the scientific research aspects of this work is sponsored by the National Science Foundation (ITR CISE-0428912, $976,825, 9/1/04 to 8/31/09; CBET-0828002; $163,558, 9/1/08 to 8/31/11; CBET-0828123, $100,000, 9/1/08 to 8/31/11; NRO-$682,000, 01/01/09 to 12/12/10; CISE/CCF-0810294, $300,000, 8/15/08 to 7/31/11; CBET-0852657, $300,000, 9/1/09 to 8/31/12; CISE/CCF-0915718, $450,000, 9/1/09 to 8/31/12; CISE/CNS-0941497, $2,016,000, 10/1/09 to 9/30/2013). The computational effort described in this request includes deterministic as well as stochastic techniques separately and, by linking them, enables multi-scale investigations of varying electrochemical interactions and applications.

We have pursued a multi-prong approach for accelerating the stochastic algorithms and the deterministic simulations, in addition to use of parallelization. Improved algorithms and code linkages developed during 2004-06 made it possible to tackle significantly more difficult applications which, during 2007-08, were targeted on early stages of electrochemical nucleation, growth, and coalescence of metal nanoclusters and thin films on various surfaces. Such phenomena occur at time and length scales that are hundreds of times smaller than the previous applications, giving rise to issues of numerical stiffness, mesh refinement, and need for accelerated methods. In addition during 2007-08, we created a new generation of algorithms along with a new generation of systems in which simulation predictions could be compared with experimental data for parameter estimation and model validation. Throughout these successive generations of studies, the overall strategy has been to use parameter sensitivity, parameter estimation, and model discrimination techniques to select the hypothesis that most likely describes experimentally-observed phenomena. Parameter sensitivity simulations, used for both parameter estimation and model selection techniques, focus on obtaining the key fundamental parameters from large sets of experimental data. In addition to the above studies, as part of this effort, we consider other electrochemical systems such as transport (electrical and chemical transport) through synthetic nanopores and electrochemical phenomena at solid-liquid interfaces. Our multiscale method development for these applications is based on (i) hierarchical integration of quantum, atomistic, mesoscale, and classical continuum theories and (ii) quasi-continuum theories where interatomic potentials are directly integrated into the continuum theories.

In this TRAC renewal proposal, we will focus on (i) improved coarse-graining methods for accurate and rapid parameter sensitivity and parameter estimation methods for electrochemical nucleation, growth, and other applications, (ii) optimization of entire complex systems composed of previously-developed multi-scale algorithms, and (iii) application of these methods to a different electrochemical systems ― lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors, synthetic ion channels, and functional surfaces. The extension to new systems will demonstrate that the algorithm and simulation developments carried out to date are also characteristic of a large class of systems where controlled shape evolution is exploited to produce desired structures. Such characteristics are ubiquitous in nanotechnology, biotechnology, and materials ― where manufacturing processes must ensure quality control at the molecular scale. The algorithms and software are generic over a broad class of problems, and will contribute well beyond the applications used in their development. The availability of such computational tools will accelerate fundamental scientific research as well as engineering design.

children.name: A-ph9
children.project_abstract:
I lead a theoretical physics group consisting of typically four postdoctoral researchers and six to eight graduate students.
We work mainly on the electronic properties of solids and liquids. Our main current focus lies in several areas of nanoscale physics. One of the burgeoning areas of research we have been focusing our effort is in the electronic properties of two-dimensional crystals that includes a variety of materials including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD), ultrathin layered oxides, graphene and boron nitride, and other combinations between group III to VI elements in the periodic table. This is one of the research areas that is being most actively pursued at the present worldwide and we are moving quickly to explain new observed phenomena and anticipate novel physics. Our theory group at UT Austin has been a world reference in this rapidly expanding area of research at the interface of solid state physics, electrical engineering, and information science.  TACC resources have been extremely helpful in keeping us at the top of this field.

children.name: cfd-pah
children.project_abstract: In this project we wish to derive hemodynamic indices associated with the blood flow dynamics in patient-specific models of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and correlate them with clinical metrics that are indicative of disease progression. The hemodynamic indices are calculated from computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations of the pulmonary arterial geometries under transient flow conditions. We wish to run these simulations using OpenFoam (an open-source CFD solver), for which user-defined functions will need to be created and compiled along with the source code. OpenFoam is highly parallelizable and scalable, so we would like to explore the feasibility of using this solver with a TACC startup allocation. We have generated approximately 30 patient-specific meshes of the aforementioned pulmonary arterial geometries. However, for startup resources we will use only one of the meshes to study the scalability of OpenFoam to solve this transient problem and evaluate the effects of time step size and number of periodic flow cycles needed to achieve time-independent results.
children.pi_institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

children.name: TG-BCS190009
children.project_abstract: One of the most difficult aspects of seismic hazard analysis is the prediction of ground motion from potential earthquakes. Accurate simulation of ground motion requires extensive knowledge of the velocity structure, source type, and site conditions in a given region; these factors must be paired with a high-resolution model mesh to predict ground motion at frequencies relevant to engineering and hazard applications. Limitations in model size and data availability often make it such that finer details in the earth model are averaged out or removed altogether, despite the fact that they could have a significant effect on predicted ground motion. In this project, we propose to examine the contribution to ground motion of an often-neglected site condition: topography. Topography has been observed to more than double earthquake ground motion in certain situations, though because of its azimuthal dependence and need for high-resolution model meshes, it is not considered in seismic hazard analysis. We will build a high-resolution mesh covering a 60km x 60km region centered on Seattle, Washington, and using the spectral element code SPECFEM3D Cartesian, run multiple rupture scenarios for Mw6.5-7.0 earthquakes on the Seattle Fault. By using high-resolution topography and a detailed 3-D velocity model, we will have an unprecedented view into the contribution of topography on seismic site response. With these tests, we will answer the question of how sensitive topographic effects are to source variability in finite fault rupture, like hypocenter location, slip distribution, and event magnitude. Paired with results from earlier tests with smaller earthquakes (Mw3.0-4.0), we will also investigate how topographic effects vary between small and large earthquakes, which have distinctly different frequency content, source distribution, and shaking duration. The results of this testing will amount to a major benchmark for the inclusion of high-resolution site conditions like topography in seismic hazard analysis.

children.name: Sandia-Fracture-Chal
children.project_abstract: Over the past two decades, the peridynamic theory has shown great promise in modeling crack initiation and growth. The theory has been mostly applied to brittle fracture; its ability to predict ductile fracture has been mostly untested. Silling et al. (2007) introduced a correspondence modeling framework for incorporating classical constitutive theories into peridynamics. Shortcomings associated with the approach, such as the unphysical problem of matter interpenetration, were reported by Tupek and Radovitzky (2014). To address the issues, they extended the original theory by incorporating non-linear bond strain measures. Recently Foster and Xu (2018) generalized Tupek’s model and presented a constitutive correspondence framework with kinematic variables (e.g. a nonlocal right Cauchy-Green deformation tensor) that can be applied directly to finite deformation plasticity. Although the model is currently limited to isotropic materials, its suitability for very large deformations over the previous peridynamic models appear to outweigh the shortcoming. This Sandia Fracture Challenge provided us an opportunity to explore the new model’s performance.
children.pi_institution: Department of Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering

children.name: TG-MSS190015
children.project_abstract:
Research motivation and objectives:  
Tungsten and tungsten alloys are being considered as leading candidates for structural and functional materials in future fusion energy devices. The most attractive properties of tungsten for the design of magnetic and inertial fusion energy reactors are its high melting point, high thermal conductivity, low sputtering yield, and low long-term disposal radioactive footprint. However, tungsten also presents a very low fracture toughness, mostly associated with inter-granular failure and bulk plasticity, that limits its applications.  W is typically alloyed with Re to increase low-temperature ductility and improve high-temperature strength and plasticity.  Given the significant neutron-induced transmutation happening in these W-Re alloys during nuclear fusion reactions, density functional theory (DFT) calculations that allow the calculation of defect and solute energetics are critical to better understand the behavior of tungsten-based materials for fusion energy applications. The research objective of this Startup Allocation proposal is to run DFT simulations (using VAST and/or Quantum Espresso) to calculate elastic and plastic mechanical properties (such as bulk modulus, shear modulus, ductility,...) on a variety of WRe-X alloys, selecting the most relevant ones for fusion applications. 

Why the project needs access to XSEDE resources?
Villanova University became a National University in 2016. To consolidate this transition, university leadership is encouraging junior faculty to initiate strong research programs. However, the high-performance computing facilities required to perform research in computational mechanics are still very limited on campus. The DFT calculations required to achieve the goals described in the previous sections are computationally intensive, and far beyond what can be done with the small cluster currently available on campus.

How the requested amounts were estimated?
The requested amounts were estimated using preliminary simulations run in a cluster with 80 cores available on campus, which has QE installed.  A total of 980 hours were required to complete all the calculations for single crystal tungsten. Then a total of 50,000 CPU-hours on Bridges and Comet and 1,600 node-hours on STampede2 were requested to allow us the most flexibility when testing 50 tentative WRe-X alloys that are subject of this study.

Why the requested resources were selected?
An email was sent to help@xsede.org on June 26, 2019 asking about the most suitable resource for the nature of the project. Based on the response received, Bridges, Comet, and Stampede2 were selected.

children.name: TG-CHE160037
children.project_abstract:
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) uses high-pressure flows in columns of micron-scale manufactured particles to achieve rapid and efficient separation of analytes into identifiable compounds. Improvements in HPLC column efficiency have been 
driven by reductions in particle size. Non-spherical, superficially porous particles (SPP) are a possibility for improving separation efficiency without further reducing the particle length scale. This research will investigate the chromatographic efficiency of ellipsoidal and spherocylindrical particles in HPLC, using pore-scale simulation methods capable of resolving flow and transport in microporous SPP.  The methods include computer algorithms for three-dimensional particle packing, viscous flow through the pore spaces of the packing, and time-dependent hydrodynamic dispersion of solutes in the flowing solvent. The methods will be applied within a general experimental design that will consider the parameters of particle shape, superficial porosity, particle orientation with respect to flow, packing volume fraction, and applied pressure drop, focusing on parameter value ranges of likely industrial significance. The experimental outcomes of broadest 
significance include the chromatographic efficiency (plate height vs velocity) and impedence (plate height vs pressure drop).
